As of Jan. 6, authorities in Albania are maintaining an indefinite 2200-0600 nationwide curfew in efforts to stem the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Residents may only leave their homes for essential work and health emergencies during curfew hours. All restaurants, bars, and cafes remain closed except for delivery services. Most nonessential businesses are permitted to open during noncurfew hours. Gatherings are limited to 10 people, and facemasks are mandatory in all indoor and outdoor public spaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118002207/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/426036/albania-authorities-to-indefinitely-maintain-covid-19-related-nationwide-2200-0600-curfew-update-17

In September, the government launched an employment promotion program, that aims to cover part of reemployment costs of those who lost their jobs during the lockdown. For formal sector employees the government will cover half of the wages (at the legal minimum level) and the full employers’ share of social contributions for the duration of the program (4 or 8 months). Informal sector employees who lost their jobs during the lockdown, will have the full cost of social contributions (employees and employers share) covered for one year if they formalize.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130223812/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government has also adopted tax deferral measures allowing all large companies (except banks, telecommunication, public enterprises and other essential businesses) to defer payment of profit tax for the second and third quarter of 2020 in 2021. A:  A total of 549 doctors, nurses, epidemiologists have been vaccinated, who are in the front line of providing services to patients with COVID. (by 21 Jan)  The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is being used.    According to the National Vaccination Plan against COVID19, the first to be vaccinated are health personnel on the front line of the fight against COVID-19, followed by those at risk who live or work in nursing homes and other groups of health workers such as and the elderly who have the highest mortality, persons who have concomitant diseases, and who take severe forms of death. People who perform other services critical to society, such as teachers, police or others, will also be vaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://shendetesia.gov.al/21-janar-vijon-vaksinimi-anticovid-vaksinohen-549-personel-shendetesor/

Antibody tests for all citizens living or working in Andorra will allow them to know the degree of immunization of COVID-19. A fact that will reinforce the control and management of the epidemiological situation and that at the same time will favour the move from a strategy of total confinement to one of selective confinement of the people infected by the coronavirus and his contacts. In this way, the protection of the most vulnerable citizens is enhanced and at the same time minimizes the probability of contagion in the work and school environment. The tests, consisting of a practically painless finger prick, will be performed free of charge to everyone.  There will be two tests to all citizens in two waves, separated by fifteen days, being the final result of the test the sum of the two tests. That is, two tests that offer a single result. In this sense, people who test positive in the first analysis of antibodies will be warned and isolated in order to take a PCR test and check if they have the disease at that time. The rest of the citizens, after the first test, will receive instructions on what to do and will obtain a final result when both tests have been done.  https://archive.vn/O1yU0

No shots in arms yet.    Press release on the government’s website from 8th January 2021:  “Regarding the vaccination process, the Holder of Health has reported that the arrival in Andorra of the first doses of the Pfizer vaccine, from Spain, will finally arrive during the incoming week, due to a delay in the administrative procedures of the pharmaceutical company. In this sense, he stated that "these administrative procedures will be resolved in the coming hours or days and that, therefore, we will be able to start vaccination immediately when we have them here".”    https://archive.vn/87rhi#selection-393.0-393.35
Still no shots in arms, no updates since the previously coded announcement.

The first doses of the SARS-CoV-2 Coronavirus vaccine arrived in Andorra on Tuesday evening. These are 1,000 units of the Pfizer vaccine from Madrid, to which will be added 1,000 more - those corresponding to the second dose of vaccination to be administered - over the next few days.  As stated by the Minister of Health, Joan Martínez Benazet, phase 1 of the vaccination campaign will begin tomorrow (Jan 20, 2021). Thus, the first vaccinated will be users of health centers and health professionals. This first vaccination round will last for two weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126110307/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12342-arriben-les-primeres-dosis-de-la-vacuna-contra-el-coronavirus

A,C:  The Minister of Health has announced the start of vaccination against COVID-19, which took place this morning in different parts of the country. The vaccination is currently aimed at residents of health centers and health professionals. The ministry believes that the administration of this first consignment will last approximately two weeks. Finally, the minister explained that in addition to the 1,000 doses received yesterday (Jan 19, 2021), 1,000 more will be added this week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126111139/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12348-administrades-les-primeres-200-dosis-de-la-vacuna-a-residents-de-centres-sociosanitaris-i-professionals-de-la-salut

A,C:  This Thursday (Jan 21, 2021), a new consignment arrived in the country with 1,000 more vaccines that will be used to administer the second dose to the first thousand people and thus achieve immunity against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126112624/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12350-andorra-s-aprovisiona-de-la-vacuna-contra-la-covid-19-seguint-els-criteris-i-mecanismes-establerts-a-europa

From 18 January, the new CoV self-tests for schoolchildren and teachers will be used in schools - but only to a limited extent due to the postponed return to face-to-face teaching. ** School closures, originally planned to end on the 25th, appear to have been extended in a limited form. **    According to the Bundesministerium, schools will continue to operate from January 25, 2021 in location-independent lessons (distance learning). Elementary school, lower secondary level schools are open for supervision and educational support. For AHS upper level, middle and higher schools, vocational schools, the location-independent lessons remain in place. Pupils should still be able to return to the schools in groups or classes on one or more days.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210122141315/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html

From 15 January, all travellers entering Austria will need to register electronically in advance and obtain a so-called pre-travel clearance (PTC). At the border, they will have to show their PTC (either digitally or as a hard copy). In parallel with this registration requirement, the current quarantine obligation remains in force until further notice, “testing oneself free” (“Freitesten”) is possible after 5 days at the earliest. Exceptions to quarantine and registration requirements apply to commuters, transients and persons entering the country for urgent family matters that cannot be postponed.  The only countries exempt from the quarantine obligation, but not from the registration requirement, are Australia, Finland, Greece, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea and Vatican.    This is applicable until 31 March 2021, further developments to be observed.    https://archive.fo/7jXrE  https://archive.vn/m4Yeg  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118175604/https://www.bmk.gv.at/service/corona/einreisebestimmungen.html
No change in policy.

23/01/2021: the landing ban for flights from the UK and South Africa has been extended until 7 February. From 25 January until 7 February, a landing ban for flights from Brazil is in effect.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126094541/https://www.austria.info/en/service-and-facts/coronavirus-information

Several measures are still in place including new phase of short-term work arrangement (until March 2021), fixed cost subsidy (March 2021), hardship fund for small businesses (March 2021). Unemployment assistance has however been discontinued end-2020.    https://archive.vn/9dis2
** No change in policy. A number of subsidies and income support policies still in effect. **

** No change in policy. **     According to emergency regulation introduced by the Wirtschaftskammer, if over-indebtedness occurs in the period from March 1, 2020 to March 31, 2021, there is no obligation (but still the possibility) of the debtor to file an application to open insolvency proceedings. In the event of insolvency, there is still an obligation to apply.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210126095617/https://www.wko.at/service/wirtschaftsrecht-gewerberecht/insolvenz-covid-19.html
No change in policy.

A second round of mass COVID testing started in Vienna, on Friday 8 January, Copied from page https://www.ruptly.tv/en/videos/20210108-032-Austria--Vienna-begins-second-COVID-mass-testing-campaign    https://archive.vn/Z72Hk      https://archive.fo/7jXrE#selection-2509.0-2511.63

Austria was to embark on a mass-testing scheme on the 15, 16 and 17 January with the obligation of a compulsory testing requirement in order to re-enter society after the lockdown. Those who received a negative test were to be allowed to leave the house and visit retail shops and hospitality (cafes and restaurants) from 18 January. Those who are not tested would be required to quarantine for another week until 25 January. For all those who were not willing to be tested, the lockdown rules were to apply a week longer. Since the lockdown has been extended until 7 February, the mass testing scheme has been scrapped.    https://archive.vn/y6WbB

** Austria on Wednesday passed a resolution in the National Council to offer coronavirus antigen tests free of charge at pharmacies across the country. The non-binding resolution is expected to become law in the coming days, Austria’s Kurier newspaper reports, after which the “free coronavirus self-tests should be distributed as soon as possible”. **    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126100826/https://www.thelocal.at/20210121/austria-to-make-coronavirus-tests-available-free-at-pharmacies

08 JanThe Austrian government promised to provide all residents older than 65 years with 10 free FFP2 masks for better protections against the coronavirus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104122951/https://metropole.at/coronavirus-in-austria-week-1-2021/

As part of the extension of the lockdown until 7 February, Austrian Chancellor declared that FFP2 masks are now required in public transport, retail and supermarkets. Previously, cotton masks or scarves were sufficient to satisfy the regulation.    While FFP2 masks are more expensive than standard medical masks, the government has promised that they will be available to Austrians at cost price. People on low incomes would be entitled to the masks for free, a government spokesperson said.    https://archive.vn/uX3BV
No change in policy.

** From 25 January medical-grade FPP2 masks are mandated in shops and on public transport. **    Wearing an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve (or an equivalent or higher-quality mask) is mandatory for the following areas:     Public transportation  Carpooling, taxis and taxi-like operations as well as at stops, stations and departure halls (also outdoors)  Cable cars and cog railways  Customer areas of commercial establishments as well as of non-body-related service companies (body-related services remain prohibited)  Connecting structures of shopping centers  Markets (indoor and outdoor)  Party traffic by administrative authorities and administrative courts  Gastronomy - if open ( e.g.  when picking up food and in company canteens)  Accommodation establishments - if open (in generally accessible areas such as the lobby or at the reception, does not apply in the room; entry is still only possible for exceptional reasons such as urgent professional purposes)    https://archive.vn/zk0aB  https://archive.vn/TAMfL

All schools continue to be closed. The virtual school platform currently supports 1.4 million users and 127,550 teachers. TV lessons are broadcasted 5-6 hours a day. And a phone hotline service is provided to support the virtual school projects.    See Ministry of Education website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210109090635/https://edu.gov.az/az/page/9/19687

In-person full-time education will be re-introduced in stages in government education institutions from 1 February 2021. Primary schools will resume in large cities 3 times per week, and in other regions 4-5 times per week. Higher and secondary vocational education institutions will continue in the form of distance learning.     See Ministry of Education website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210124063323/https://edu.gov.az/az/page/9/19805

Government agencies are limiting office staff to 30 percent of manpower, whilst other employees are required to work remotely.    Shopping centres are currently restricted to operating via delivery services and online sales. Personal care businesses, such as barbershops and beauty salons, are also closed.   All the above will re-open on 25 January 2021. Cinemas, theatres, religious rituals, and sports events remain closed or prohibited. Schools are open with sanitation requirements- e.g. in some schools there is both online and in person teaching to reduce contact  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115144807if_/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/#id_6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115151046/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/belgian-high-schoolers-demand-to-get-back-inperson-learning-students-school-students-learning-coronavirus-pandemic-b1786453.html  All pupils can go to school but social distancing measures are in place https://web.archive.org/web/20210115144807/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/ The school follows a  plan with measures against corona . This way your child stays safe. The plan has 4 phases: green, yellow, orange and red. Each phase has different measures. The measures differ per educational level. All primary and secondary schools will start in code orange from 16 November. Part-time art education and adult education will start in code red from 16 November. Are there more infections in your municipality? Then there may be an orange or red phase in your school. Your municipality and your school will give you more information. Staff, students and parents also adhere to the precautions. The school can take more measures if it deems it necessary. You will then receive more information. If a person becomes infected, the CLB follows a step-by-step plan. https://web.archive.org/web/20210115145823/https://onderwijs.vlaanderen.be/nl/node/9335#e9444d2c-8021-49da-8ddd-29c415ca07d0

No policy changes.    You may travel to Belgium when:  You are a resident of the European Union, Schengen Area or the United Kingdom.  You are travelling from a country that has been included in the list of the FPS Foreign Affairs.    All other countries are banned from travelling to Belgium. You may only travel from these countries to Belgium for an essential reason. A list of the essential reasons can be found in the frequently asked questions.  https://archive.vn/8JWx9    Note that:  From Monday 25 January, all travellers travelling to Belgium from the UK, South Africa and South America will be required to be quarantined for 10 days with a PCR test on day 1 and day 7.  From 27 January, international traffic will be further restricted. During the period of the ban, only essential travel is permitted.  Also, every non-resident travelling to Belgium will need to provide a negative test prior to departure, and will be tested again on arrival in Belgium. This can be done with a PCR test or a rapid antigen test.  https://archive.vn/3XQmF

No policy changes. Comprehensive contact tracing in place.    Process explained as follows:    Do you test positive?  •	Stay in isolation for at least 7 days.  •	The persons living in your house must be in quarantine.  •	Try to make a list of the people you have had contact with in the past days. Think about the people you met from two days before you had symptoms (e.g. your colleagues, a friend you went for a walk with, your own family members, the postman, etc.).  •	Your list of contacts should preferably include their name, telephone number, address, date of birth and e-mail address.  A government employee will call you from the number 02/214.19.19. It is important that you answer the employee’s questions as fully as possible:  •	He or she will ask you about the list of contacts you drew up.  •	You should give some extra information about yourself in order to be able to assess the situation as concretely as possible: your date of birth, general state of health, profession, contact with people at risk, etc.  This data will be treated confidentially. Thanks to your contribution, your contacts can be notified in good time and they can follow up any symptoms well.    https://archive.vn/IgGHs
No policy change https://web.archive.org/web/20210107174326/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

As previous, required everywhere in Brussels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165247/https://www.brussels.be/face-mask-brussels And in specific places in the rest of the country https://web.archive.org/web/20210107174326/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

No policy changes.    Since Monday 26 October 2020, wearing a face mask is mandatory in Brussels throughout the Brussels-Capital Region (from 12 years). The face mask has to cover the mouth and nose.  https://archive.vn/P0wEi    In the rest of the country, masks are mandatory in a variety of specific places:    Everyone, with the exception of children up to the age of 12, is obliged to cover their mouth and nose with a face mask or any other fabric alternative in all situations where it is impossible to ensure compliance with the rules of social distancing. This last obligation does not apply to:  •	people living under the same roof;  •	children mixing up to the age of 12;  •	people meeting each who have close contact on a regular basis;  •	counsellors and their clients (people in need of counselling).  In addition, wearing a face mask is compulsory in a number of places, regardless of the number of people present there:  •	On public transport from entering the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport drivers are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  •	For supervisors of camps, training sessions and activities that are allowed;  •	The establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for customers and staff, unless whilst eating, drinking or sitting at a table;  •	In shops and shopping centres;  •	In shopping streets, at markets and in any private or public are with significant footfall, which is determined by the competent local authority and demarcated by a notice specifying the times at which the obligation applies;  •	In conference rooms, auditoriums and places of worship & reflection;  •	In libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  •	in museums;  •	In places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  •	When moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman.  When it is not possible to wear a face mask or any fabric alternative due to medical reasons, a face shield can be worn.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123121642if_/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/#id_7

C:    On 21 December 2020, the EMA issued a positive opinion on the biontech/Pfizer vaccine and it was subsequently approved by the European Commission. On 28 December, this vaccine was administered for the first time in 3 Belgian residential care centres (located in Puurs, Brussels and Mons). From 5 January, this vaccination will be rolled out in all residential care centres. Currently, vaccines from two other companies, Moderna and Astra Zeneca/Oxford, are also undergoing the strict control of the EMA. The Moderna vaccine will be reviewed on 6 January 2021. If successful, the European Commission can give its final approval and green light for the use of this vaccine. Other potential vaccines will be examined later, including those from Johnson & Johnson or Curevac.      Will the vaccine be available to everyone from the start?  No. The vaccines will be produced continuously and quantity available will increase as they are delivered. Pending their large-scale production, several steps should be planned to best protect the most vulnerable groups and gradually increase individual immunity. (see question “Who are the priority groups?")  At the moment, it is difficult to provide a precise schedule for the administration of these vaccines. Therefore, monitoring the progressive availability of the vaccine per priority group is crucial.    To increase the population’s immunity and to protect those most vulnerable from the virus, vaccination will take place in three phases, depending on the number of doses available.    GROUP 1a    First, the most vulnerable and exposed people will be vaccinated.    Residents and employees of residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit elderly people hard, especially those living in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, followed by the staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  The medical staff from primary care and hospitals: they are in close contact with patients with Covid-19 on a daily basis. To protect them, they are vaccinated as a matter of priority.  Next, the other staff in hospitals and health services will be vaccinated, including organisations responsible for prevention activities, such as vaccination and cancer screening centres, ONE and Kind en Gezin.  In this first phase, this will require a special organisation and infrastructure (extremely low storage temperatures, multiple doses, etc.).    GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical problems but at high risk    In this phase it is expected that vaccines will become more widely available. It will then be possible to vaccinate larger groups of people. Priority will be given to people outside the hospital who are most at risk. These are the following groups:    People over 65: people over 65 are the first priority at this stage. If sufficient vaccine is available, all these people can be vaccinated at the same time. Otherwise we start with the oldest people and then work our way down.  People between 45-65 years of age with an increased risk: Then people between 45-65 years come with risk factors, such as:  Diabetes,  Hypertension, Chronic cardiovascular, pulmonary, kidney and liver disorders, haematological cancers up to 5 years after diagnosis,  All recent cancers (or recent cancer treatments)  Obesity (Body Mass Index = 30).  This list will be updated and expanded in the light of scientific developments,    Essential professions: In this phase, people with essential social and/or economic professions are vaccinated. In this second phase, we can expect fewer logistical bottlenecks and organising the vaccination will be easier for these target groups.  GROUP 2 - general population    Thirdly, vaccine doses will be available in sufficient quantities to vaccinate the rest of the population.    At this stage it can be expected that the doses can be stored and administered like other vaccines such as the flu vaccine).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165454/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/    Note: Belgium was criticised for being slow off the mark with vaccinations:  About 700 residents and staff of care homes have gotten their first shot as of January 2, when the government provided its latest update on the tally. In Germany, by contrast, roughly 317,000 doses have been administered, and about 182,000 in Italy. Yves Van Laethem, an infectious diseases specialist and spokesman for Belgium's COVID-19 crisis center, said the country is also getting fewer doses than initially promised by Pfizer — only 320,000 instead of 600,000 by late December — forcing the government to make a choice between healthcare workers and the elderly. They said they would prioritise the elderly. Hence only one group have been vaccinated in this early stage.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210107121941/https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-government-criticism-coronavirus-vaccine-campaign-frank-vandenbroucke/    Other notes:  Belgium received its first batch of 9,750 vaccines last Saturday (Dec 26, 2020) and began vaccinating  between 300 and 400 people today.     Residents and staff of care homes and health care professionals will be the first to be vaccinated. Vaccinations started in three care homes across Belgium (Woluwe-Saint-Pierre in Brussels, Mons in Wallonia and Puurs in Flanders, where the BioNTech/Pfizer vaccine was produced).    Under the second phase of the plan, people over 65, patients between 45 and 65 years old at high risk from the virus due to obesity or lung disease, and people with essential jobs will get their shot. Finally, other at-risk patients and the rest of the adult population will be vaccinated.    The timing of the different phases will depend on how many doses are available at different times, and how difficult it is to store the vaccines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165332/https://www.euronews.com/2020/12/28/covid-vaccine-man-96-is-first-to-receive-coronavirus-jab-in-belgium  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104165542/https://www.politico.eu/article/what-you-need-to-know-about-belgiums-vaccination-strategy/

The government announced it is updating its Covid-19 vaccination roll-out plan which has been widely criticized for being slow. Only 700 doses were used, out of the 10,000+ vaccine doses delivered on December 28, 2020.     Professor Corinne Vandermeulen, a professor at the KU Leuven Vaccinology Department says, "we're doing the best we can. And of course there can be critics and I know that people criticize the fact that we choose to vaccinate the people in the long term care facilities first and that we might have started with healthcare workers maybe first instead of the elderly. But the elderly, they are the most vulnerable."    By the start of this week, only 700 of the over 10 thousand vaccine doses delivered to Belgium by an EU scheme on December 28th had been put into people's arms.    The only jab approved in the EU so far is the one from Pfizer-BioNtech.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107181631/https://www.euronews.com/2021/01/06/belgium-to-launch-new-coronavirus-vaccine-strategy-amid-criticism-for-a-slow-roll-out

As of 3 January, orders RD-01-719 and RD-01-725 remain in effect.    A temporary ban has been introduced for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons, regardless of their citizenship, through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport.     The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia, the Republic of Serbia and the Republic of Albania Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; the persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holders of a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons who have a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or in a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and members of their families.     A temporary ban has been introduced for entering the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport of all persons arriving with a starting point of departure from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.    The prohibition does not apply to Bulgarian citizens and persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria, to members of their families, as well as to other groups of persons specified in the order.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102180723/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 3 January, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news briefings, video materials, and information about COVID-19 in Bulgaria.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. Users can also voluntarily share their location to enable institutions to act accordingly, in case of an emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214232020/https://virusafe.info/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102214833/https://coronavirus.bg/

As of 3 January, testing procedures depend on whether the individual is a first- or second-line contact person, suffers from a chronic illness, falls into the risk category of people over 60, is a medical professional, and has symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral (can be issued electronically or on paper) by a general practitioner.    A referral for a PCR test will also be issued to individuals who test positive for a rapid antigen test performed by an authorized medical care provider.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102215235/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

Banking Agencies have announced a six-month loan repayment moratorium for restructuring credit arrangements for individuals and legal entities which are found to have aggravated circumstances for loans repayments due to COVID-19. Banking Agencies have instructed banks to track clients and exposure portfolios affected by COVID-19. Banks are also instructed to consider additional customer relief, including reviewing current fees for services and avoiding charging fees to handle exposure modifications. All banks were ordered not to pay dividends or bonuses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109060549/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Bosnia and Herzegovina has still not started vaccination. Since the country is completely dependent on the COVAX system, the first vaccinations are not expected until mid-February. Between 5,000 and 10,000 doses are expected in the first delivery. So far, vaccinations are only available for 20% of the population. Direct purchases of Pfizer, Sputnik V and Sinopharm vaccinations are expected to vaccinate another 20% of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010146/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

No new income support announced. Also, Prime Minister Roman Golovchenko said that the government did not see a slowdown in economic activity in Belarus amidst the second wave of COVID-19 and the social commitments of the state were not only fulfilled, but also over-fulfilled as the average salary reached Br1,300.     “The 8.9% increase in real household income is another testimony to the efficient economic performance,”    “Despite the difficult situation our economy is performing quite well, much better than the economies of many of our neighbors, including the economically stronger ones. According to preliminary estimates, our gross domestic product this year will be at least as big as 99% of last year's. This is the main economic outcome. It is very encouraging that the manufacturing industry has bounced back in recent months,”    “Even when the whole world is struggling through the coronavirus second wave, we do not see a slowdown in economic activity in our country so far,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095057/https://eng.belta.by/economics/view/pm-no-economic-slowdown-in-belarus-amidst-coronavirus-second-wave-136198-2020/    Considering the official stand of the Belarus' government regarding Covid-19, new financial/economic/fiscal measures seem unlikely within the upcoming months at least.

“A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations (Sputnik V) against COVID-19. Medical staff and teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated (tachers later on, however, see below). Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0    "Now we continue vaccinating healthcare workers. We expect the next batch to arrive in the near future. Teachers will be next in line for a COVID-19 vaccine. In the first quarter of this year, we are set to release the Sputnik V vaccine under the Belarusian brand, together with Russian colleagues at the Belarus-based Belmedpreparaty pharmaceutical company,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120121234/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/minister-pneumonia-cases-keep-declining-in-belarus-136636-2021/    Unable to find evidence regarding funding so have recorded government funded for now, as vaccine is voluntary and only available to certain groups, suggesting that it couldn't be purchased privately (individually funded)

Recoded from 1G to 2G, as there is still a nationwide ban on in-person higher education in place, even if some exceptions to the remote learning rule are allowed in practice (e.g. medical dissections).     Original coding note:     Compulsory schools: Face-to-face teaching is permitted. Schools must implement precautionary measures.    Upper secondary schools (e.g. baccalaureate and vocational schools): Classroom teaching is permitted.     Schools must implement precautionary measures. Everyone on site must also wear a mask. There is no restriction on group size for sports tuition and this may also be held in sports halls. The requirements concerning physical distancing and/or the wearing of masks must be observed.    Tertiary level (e.g. universities and other higher education institutions): Face-to-face teaching is permitted only if the students absolutely need to be on site (e.g. instruction on operating a particular machine, dissection during medical studies) and if the teaching forms an essential part of the course of study. Otherwise, a switch to remote learning is required. Examinations linked to study courses or higher vocational training and the examinations necessary for obtaining an official certificate may be held on site provided that the precautionary measures are observed..    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#850493620

In addition to national ban on in-person higher education, some canons have taken the step to close specific school levels in addition. [***coded as 2G to reflect the national policy on universities; however, not coded as a 3T as in no location are ALL levels of schools closed. Localized measures only address some levels of schools, not meeting the threshold for a 3T]     "However, the canton of Aargau decided on Wednesday to close its secondary schools and professional schools and continue classes via online learning from next Monday until the end of February. One aim is to reduce the number of students on public transport.    On Thursday, the canton of Solothurn decided to close its secondary schools and professional schools and continue classes via online learning from next Monday until at least 26 February 2021. It is also extending mask wearing to primary school children from the 5th year."    https://archive.vn/PwWqY#selection-521.0-525.271

Closed nationwide as of Jan 6: • Restaurants and bars • Discos and nightclubs • Cultural institutions • Sports facilities • Recreational facilities  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111222809/https://www.bag.admin.ch/dam/bag/en/dokumente/mt/k-und-i/aktuelle-ausbrueche-pandemien/2019-nCoV/regeln-empfehlungen.pdf.download.pdf/Measures.pdf

Restaurants, cultural venues, and sports and leisure facilities are to remain closed until the end of February.     It is also introducing new measures to drastically reduce contact between people. From Monday, 18 January, there will be a requirement to work from home, shops selling non-essential goods will be closed, stricter rules will apply to private events and gatherings, and measures to protect those at especially high risk will be strengthened in the workplace.    https://archive.vn/Sft4a#selection-3399.0-3405.1    Museums, cinemas, casinos, botanical gardens and zoos, and also other cultural and recreational facilities, are closed. In libraries and archives, only the reading rooms are closed; it is still possible to borrow books.    Discotheques and dance venues are closed. Dance events may not be held.    Sports and wellness facilities are closed. This includes fitness centres, artificial ice rinks and swimming pools. The following remain open: ski areas, equestrian sports facilities and facilities in hotels which are only accessible to hotel guests.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#accordion1611333018502

"From Monday, 18 January, there will be a requirement to work from home", however, a closer inspection of policy reveals that it is only mandatory that "Employers will be required to enable all staff to work from home where it is feasible and practicable for them to do so based on the type of activity. Employers will not be required to assume expenses incurred by employees for electricity or rent etc. as this is a temporary measure." For that reason, coded as a 2G rather than 3G since employees in certain sectors still are able to go to work or choose not to work from home even when given the option.     https://archive.vn/Sft4a#selection-3399.0-3405.1

Nationwide ban on public events and a maximum of 5 people at cultural and sporting activities as of Jan 6.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111222809/https://www.bag.admin.ch/dam/bag/en/dokumente/mt/k-und-i/aktuelle-ausbrueche-pandemien/2019-nCoV/regeln-empfehlungen.pdf.download.pdf/Measures.pdf

No policy changes.    Events are basically prohibited (with some exceptions).    Professional competitive events and events with spectators/audience are banned. If there are no spectators/audience (e.g. for television broadcasts) they are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#accordion1611333018502

Private meetings limited to a maximum of 10 people nationwide as of Jan 6 (some cantons have stricter rules).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111222809/https://www.bag.admin.ch/dam/bag/en/dokumente/mt/k-und-i/aktuelle-ausbrueche-pandemien/2019-nCoV/regeln-empfehlungen.pdf.download.pdf/Measures.pdf

No more than five people may attend private gatherings. Children are also included in that number. Gatherings of people in public are also limited to five people.     https://archive.vn/Sft4a#selection-3399.0-3405.1

Public transport continues to operate.    https://archive.vn/FEfwy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#accordion1611333018502

Staying at home recommended nationwide as of Jan 06: https://web.archive.org/web/20210111222809/https://www.bag.admin.ch/dam/bag/en/dokumente/mt/k-und-i/aktuelle-ausbrueche-pandemien/2019-nCoV/regeln-empfehlungen.pdf.download.pdf/Measures.pdf

Recommended, but no curfews.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#accordion1611333018502

Individuals from the Schengen area and EU as well as certain other countries can enter. Ban to enter for people from all other countries except for special circumstances.    No entry allowed from UK and South Africa to contain the spread of new variants of the virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119115107/https://www.sem.admin.ch/sem/de/home/sem/aktuell/einreisebeschraenkungen-drittstaaten.html

On December 18, 2020, the parliament agreed on an additional article in the Covid-19 law. Accordingly, people with an income of up to 3470 francs receive 100% compensation for Kurzarbeit (in which they only work 20%~ of their hours and the employers get to keep them on their contracts while not paying most of their salary). For incomes between 3470 and 4340 francs, Kurzarbeit compensation for complete loss of earnings is also 3470 francs; partial loss of earnings will be calculated proportionally. The classification of Kurzarbeit wages takes place on the basis of the salary extrapolated to a full-time workload. The regular compensation of 80% applies from 4,340 francs. The regulation is directly applicable. It applies retrospectively from December 1, 2020 and is limited to March 31, 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200505220259/https://www.arbeit.swiss/secoalv/de/home/menue/institutionen-medien/projekte-massnahmen/pandemie.html
No policy changes (see details in previous coding update).    https://archive.vn/aJ47x
No policy changes. Did not find any information about debt/contract relief for households.
No policy changes, in-depth and detailed information via government websites. See sources for other coding entries as source / evidence.
No policy changes, cost for tests continue to be covered only for people with symptoms or close contacts of someone with a positive test result.    https://archive.vn/Boi4u

No policy changes. Comprehensive contact tracing continues to operate.  https://archive.vn/2cMia    Swisscovid app offered for contact tracing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124121656/https://foph-coronavirus.ch/swisscovid-app/

Masks must be worn in many public spaces, for example in shops, in restaurants, on public transport and in busy pedestrian zones. Further details can be found on the Masks page. The general rule of thumb applies: Always wear a mask when you are away from home and unable to maintain social distancing of 1.5 metres from other people at all times.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#accordion1611333018502    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122618/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/masken.html#11550956

B,C: Pfizer/BioNTech      Vaccination was started in most cantons on 4 January 2021. Especially vulnerable people are being vaccinated first.   The following people are to be given access to vaccinations first:  * People age 75 and over  * People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109120317/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Second vaccine - Moderna - approved for use on January 12.     B;C     Targeted groups amended to explicitly identify care home/retirement home residents and staff : "The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time."     However, still coded as two groups rather than three as "key workers" are not categorically being vaccinated; rather, only some care/retirement home staff has the option of vaccination.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Recoded from 1G to 2G as official government policy allows for both B & C to access vaccine nationally, despite lags or variation in localized vaccine rollout. Not coded as 3G as "key workers" are not able to categorically access the vaccine; rather only a limited portion of care/retirement home workers have the option of vaccination.     B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    Original coding note:     Note that the federal policy is to give access first to A, B and C:    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:  ?	People age 75 and over  ?	People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  ?	People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    However, the status is that only elderly people are indeed getting shots in arms in all cantons. In some cantons B and C are vaccinated. In Zurich, A and C. In others, only C (detailed sources below). Based on the coding guidance that Geographic coverage needs to be national before this is coded, as we code the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, changing to 1G.  Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNTec, Moderna. Undergoing approval process: AstraZeneca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110150607/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    Clinically vulnerable people under 75 now also being vaccinated as well, e.g. in Zug:  https://archive.vn/v7s4P  and Baselland:  https://archive.vn/KPry4    But the roll out varies across cantons, e.g. in Basel-city only the elderly over 75 are being invited to get vaccinated.  https://archive.vn/WVWiv  https://archive.vn/hJDAb    Similarly, in Bern, where only people over 75 years old are being vaccinated for now.  https://archive.vn/rRwCL#selection-1591.0-1595.92    In Zurich, residents and staff in elderly care home have started to receive vaccines.   https://archive.vn/cZiRN  In Tessin, elderly care home residents and staff, as well as the over 85-year-olds can book vaccinations.  https://archive.vn/T29oA    Note there are reports of a slow roll out of the vaccine program.  https://archive.vn/ukR7N

From 5am on 10 January, until at least midnight on 31 January, all outings from your place of residence require permission granted either by sending an SMS to “8998” from a Cypriot mobile number, or by completing and carrying a written form if you do not have a Cypriot phone number (or are over 65 and prefer this method). You are also required to carry official identification at all times.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214091800/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cyprus/coronavirus

Until at least January 31, a strict island-wide curfew is in effect from 09:00pm to 05:00am with the exceptions of emergency medical reasons and employees with a letter from their employer.     Approval by sending an SMS to 8998 is required to leave one’s residence until at least January 31 (people over 65 can use a printed form). Each resident is permitted two permissions a day. Exceptions are made for dog-walking, taking children to school, and employment.   no changes in policy: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125235223/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.25614906.681852430.1611618647-385059307.1606168314

The government has approved additional financial assistance for business owners who have had to close their doors due to the COVID-necessitated restriction.   This will amount to 400 CZK per employee, applied retrospectively from the 14th of October 2020 to 10th January 2021. The first call of the subsidy will amount to 2.5 billion crowns.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210109194821/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/government-approves-further-aid-for-closed-premises--wants-to-extend-easier-administration-of-social-benefits-during-pandemic-185930/

The vaccine used currently is the Pfizer/BioNTech inoculation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101213613/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/when-we-will-have-vaccine

A, C  In connection with the launching of the vaccination campaign, the Ministry of Health received permission from the government to issue two extraordinary measures relating to vaccination against COVID-19, coming into effect 14 January. The first allows vaccination against COVID-19 to be carried out on all clients of domestic health insurance companies who express an interest, in line with the vaccination strategy. The second orders vaccination sites to input into a special module of the Infectious Disease Information System without delay all necessary information on the distribution and movement of vaccines so as to ensure uniform and accurate records.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210116172650/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/government-acquaints-itself-with-vaccination-strategy-for-the-czech-republic--vaccination-sites-must-start-reporting-on-vaccine-consumption-186055/

All shops must close. Only supermarkets and shops for everyday basic needs may remain open. Cafés, restaurants and bars remain closed but may offer take away or delivery services. Curfew between 8pm/9pm/10pm (depending on state) and 5am remains in place in Baden-Württemberg, Bayern, Sachsen, Bradenburg, and Thüringen, during which leaving the house is only allowed under very limited circumstances (e.g. medical emergencies). Between 5am and 8pm/9pm/10pm, there are more exceptions, including going to the supermarket, going to work (provided it is required and allowed under other restrictions), and exercise. In Berlin, you can only leave the house with "valid reasons" (effectively exceptions).    Other states have mostly adopted the federal guidelines limiting movement to within 15km around one's home whenever incidence over the past 7 days is above 200 infections/100000 residents. Mecklenburg-Vorpommern,       At least Bremen, Niedersachsen and Hamburg seem to have no such restrictions, making 2T the best fit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210130185647/https://www.focus.de/gesundheit/coronavirus/corona-regeln-naechtliche-ausgangssperre-in-welchen-bundeslaendern-sie-immer-noch-gilt_id_12858482.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130191559/https://www.pnn.de/brandenburg/lockdown-bis-zum-31-januar-2021-das-ist-in-potsdam-und-brandenburg-erlaubt/26739656.html

Individuals travelling from certain countries, such as the UK, are banned from entering Denmark.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108132907/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/persons-arriving-in-denmark-from-the-uk

Citizens of all countries have been banned from entering Denmark from January 9 until January 18, as part of the country’s efforts to prevent the further spread of the Coronavirus pandemic, precisely due to the new mutation of the virus found in Britain and some other countries.    In addition, Denmark’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has urged all its citizens to avoid travelling to other countries due to the disease’s rapid spread, SchengenVisaInfo.com reports.    The latest announcement of Denmark’s authorities clarified that the whole world would be “sharpened from being orange to red.”    Denmark’s Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod has stressed that the new mutations of the Coronavirus pandemic, spread in several other countries pose a significant risk that Denmark’s infection rates may escalate.      “The safety and security of Danes is the government’s priority. We can see the finish line. The vaccine is here. We must not stumble on the run-up stretch. Not least in the light of the new mutations, we will have to – all of us – make an extra effort. And today’s package of travel initiatives is an expression of that,” says Foreign Minister Jeppe Kofod.    Recently Denmark announced plans to impose a digital ‘vaccine passport’ which would permit all vaccinated citizens against COVID-19 disease to travel to countries which oblige citizens to have such a document, in order to be able to enter these countries.    According to the Danish Health Ministry, the ‘vaccine passport will be rolled out in early 2021,” and all those vaccinated would be eligible to obtain the document through Denmark’s public health website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111123210/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/denmark-temporarily-bans-from-entering-citizens-of-all-countries/    From 5:00 p.m. on 9 January 2021 through 7 February 2021, Denmark has instituted a flight ban on the transport of passengers, including Danish citizens, who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours before departure.   https://archive.vn/eOv2R

To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.  The ban will allow passenger flights only under the condition, that all passengers onboard the airplane have been tested negative for COVID-19 within 24 hours of boarding the plane. Children under the age of 12 will be excluded from the test requirement  http://web.archive.org/web/20210115173415/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/regarding-passengers-travelling-to-denmark-by-air

The Danish border closure – imposed on March 14 – remains in place for. Only travelers residents who qualify for a travel exception (called a “worthy purpose” by the Danish government) can enter Denmark. Some travel exceptions include having a valid residence permit for Denmark, attending a business meeting, or being the spouse, parent, or child of a Danish citizen or legal resident in Denmark.      To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.    The flight ban will enter into force 9 January 2021 at 5pm and last until the end of 28 February 2021.    Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210130124651/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/persons-resident-in-countries-outside-of-denmark

If you are not ill and want to be tested  If you have no symptoms and want to be tested for coronavirus, book an appointment on coronoprover.dk.      https://archive.vn/PRbUh
Anyone can be tested if they would like to be https://archive.vn/TVhLk http://web.archive.org/web/20210115175357/https://coronasmitte.dk/test-og-smitteopsporing

You should be tested if:    -You have symptoms that could be COVID-19  -You are told that you are in close contact with a person who is infected with a new coronavirus  -You are told that you must be tested prior to, for example, hospitalization, treatment or examination  -You are told that you must be tested as part of infection detection in the event of an outbreak, eg in primary schools, in day care institutions, in nursing homes, etc.  -You are told that you are 'another contact', and must be tested as soon as possible, eg via Infection | stop the app   -You go to work    The regions and the government have entered into agreements with private suppliers to conduct free rapid tests for all Danes. A rapid test (also called an antigen test) detects virus proteins in a sample and is taken by a nasal swab. The rapid test is less sensitive than the PCR test and therefore does not provide an equally reliable answer.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131819/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/test-
People have to call the hotline if they have been in contact with someone who has had it http://web.archive.org/web/20210115181736/https://coronasmitte.dk/coronaopsporing

If you are infected with COVID-19, you are encouraged to contact the Danish Agency for Patient Safety Corona Detection as soon as possible on tel. 32 32 05 11. In any case, Corona Detection tries to contact the infected person within 24 hours after being notified of a positive test result from the Statens Serum Institut (or private test providers), to offer help in locating and contacting the close contacts who may be infected, and thus can also infect others. The infected person is offered help to call and advise the close contacts. It is voluntary if you want help with this task. As an infected person, you can also be responsible for informing close contacts and referring them. The Danish Agency for Patient Safety contacts citizens both by telephone and letter in e-Boks    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131217/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/smitteopsporing

Persons aged 12 and over must wear a bandage or visor in the following places:  In public transport, etc., including in trains, buses, taxis, ferries, as well as at station areas and stops, etc.  At restaurants where food, drinks or tobacco are served for consumption at the point of sale.  In the retail trade, including in department stores, grocery stores, department stores, department stores, department stores, bazaars, arcades, places that sell food and beverages that are not consumed at the point of sale (take-away), etc.  In premises where cultural, sports and association activities are carried out, including museums, sports halls, fitness centers, art galleries, venues, libraries, cultural centers, zoos, cinemas, theaters, association rooms, etc.  In rooms where the Danish National Church and denominations outside the Danish National Church carry out activities.  In job centers and in citizen service centers.  At institutions that carry out preparatory education, youth education, Danish education for adult foreigners, etc., adult and continuing education, higher education, Folkeuniversitetet, day colleges, evening schools, music and culture schools, driving schools that carry out theory teaching, and folk high schools, etc.  Public and private hospitals and clinics, clinics, etc. in the practice sector, municipal health services, municipal and private care centers and nursing homes, relief places as well as a number of placements and housing facilities in the social area.  During the conduct of practical driving tests, indicative health driving tests and at final tests in driving when one is in a vehicle with others.    Thus, there is no general requirement to wear a bandage or visor in all rooms to which the public has access.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124101122/https://coronasmitte.dk/mundbind-og-visir

The current restrictions include the mandatory face mask use in indoor public areas.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120629/https://www.thelocal.dk/20210127/dont-expect-denmark-to-reopen-at-start-of-february-minister    Wearing a face mask is obligatory:  - On public transport etc., including trains, busses, taxis and ferries, and at train stations and bus stops, etc.  - In establishments selling food, drinks or tobacco for consumption on-site.  - In retail shops, including supermarkets, shopping centres, department stores, bazaars and shopping arcades, takeaway restaurants, etc.  - Indoors in premises for cultural, sports and recreational activities, including museums, sports centres, fitness centres, art galleries, music venues, libraries, cultural centres, zoos, cinemas, theatres and clubs as well as job centres, citizen service centres, etc.   - Indoors in churches or other places of worship.  - At institutions of learning – such as preparatory education, upper secondary schools, adult and continuing education programmes, institutions of higher education, universities, folk high schools, night school, schools of music and arts, driving schools offering theory lessons, etc.  In public and private hospitals and clinics, independent therapists, municipal healthcare services, municipal and private nursing care and assisted living facilities, respite care facilities, as well as foster care facilities and institutions for people with mental disorders or special needs in the social care sector.  - While taking your driving test, including assessing the fitness to drive tests, when others are in the car with you.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130121532/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Prevent-infection/Face-masks

A, B:    Denmark begins vaccinating against COVID from 27 December.    Vulnerable people and front-line health sector workers will be the first to receive it    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106171203/https://covid19.ssi.dk/overvagningsdata/vaccinationstilslutning    https://web.archive.org/web/20201217144136/https://www.thelocal.dk/20201217/coronavirus-denmark-hopes-to-begin-vaccine-programme-on-december-27th

According to the official calendar, up to the current date the Danish Health Authority has determined that the target groups for the vaccination programme should be given priority in the following order:  - Residents in nursing homes, etc. & People aged = 65 years who receive both personal care and practical assistance.  - Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.  - Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.  - Selected relatives of persons at significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as carers.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130122057/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Vaccinationskalender-A4-webtilgaengelig.ashx?la=da&hash=5234BB82243B24FD492FDDAC1388CA9A22BC83D6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123050/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination-against-COVID-19/Target-groups  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130123058/https://www.sst.dk/-/media/Udgivelser/2021/Corona/Vaccination/Kalender/Specificeret-vaccinationskalender.ashx?la=da&hash=C2818CB774B7C56FCC64981CD7D6B3752EA026AF      The first approved vaccine against COVID-19 is called Comirnaty® and was developed by the German company BioNTech in collaboration with the American company Pfizer. The deliveries of Comirnaty® that we receive to Denmark are produced in factories in Germany and Belgium.   The second vaccine, which is approved for use in the EU and thus Denmark, has been developed by the American company Moderna. COVID-19 vaccine Moderna® is developed on the same technology as Comirnaty®, and is produced in factories in Switzerland and Spain.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130132848/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/vaccination

On January 7, the government decided to resume contact education in general education schools, vocational schools and universities outside Harju County and Ida-Viru County as of January 11.     In Harju and Ida-Viru County, 1-4th, 9th and 12th grade students will return to in person teaching. The remaining grades will remain online.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210117193919/https://www.hm.ee/en/spread-covid-19-recommendations-educational-institutions

The government has decided to ease from today, 18 January, some of the restrictions imposed in Harju and Ida-Viru counties in December to limit the spread of the coronavirus, reports ERR.  In-person learning at all levels of education will be restored from 25 January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122241/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/estonia-eases-some-covid-19-restrictions-7025

Restrictions are expanded in Harju County and Ida-Viru County from the 28th of December. All entertainment services must close. All catering company premises are closed to customers, however food takeaway and delivery services are permitted. All sports facilities must be closed to visitors. However this does not apply to professional athletes or those with special needs.   Indoor youth work, hobby activities, further education/informal education is no longer permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

Harju and Ida-Viru counties -  Restaurants, cafes and other catering establishments may resume on-site service, staying open between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. at up to 25 percent of their maximum capacity. Hobby activities and hobby education, refresher (additional) training and continuing education, youth work, sporting and training sessions will be allowed indoors as individual activities only. Inside museums and exhibition facilities, visitor numbers are capped at 50 percent of the premises’ capacity.   Alcoholic drinks cannot be sold from midnight to 10 a.m. until 26 January. From 27 January until 28 February, the ban on selling alcohol is extended from 10 p.m. to 10 a.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122241/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/estonia-eases-some-covid-19-restrictions-7025

In Harju County and Ida-Viru County, public meetings and events are prohibited. This includes conferences, theatre performances, indoor cinema viewing, museum and exhibition viewing.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

Harju and Ida-Viru counties -  Public meetings and events, including conferences, theatre performances, concerts and movie screenings, are prohibited indoors. Outdoors, they can be attended in groups of up to ten people, with no contact between groups allowed. A public outdoor event must be over by 10 p.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122241/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/estonia-eases-some-covid-19-restrictions-7025

In Harju County and Ida-Viru Count, from the 28th of December a maximum of 10 people can take part in meetings outdoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101134054/https://www.valitsus.ee/en/news/government-imposes-restrictions-similar-ida-virumaa-harju-county-and-agreed-additional-support

The government has established a pre-entry and post-entry testing procedure for entering Estonia from a country with a high risk of coronavirus infection, coming into force on the 15th of January.   Those who want to avoid self-isolation must take a PCR test up to 72 hours before arrival in Estonia. While staying in Estonia, it is then possible to take a second test from the 6th day after the first test taken abroad.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210117194539/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-has-established-testing-procedure-upon-arrival-estonia-countries-high-risk-0

The Estonian vaccination drive began on 27th of December. Healthcare workers (group A) are the first to be vaccinated, using the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210101212336/https://news.err.ee/1220851/over-200-health-care-workers-receive-covid-19-vaccination-on-first-day

In the first two weeks of vaccination, 10,197 people have received the first dose of coronavirus vaccine at 100 healthcare facilities in Estonia.    The first dose has been given to most of the staff of family medicine centers, approximately 30 percent of the staff of the hospitals in the hospital network, as well as the staff and residents of the first care homes, the Ministry of Social Affairs said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123120628/https://www.baltictimes.com/more_than_10_000_people_in_estonia_have_received_1st_dose_of_coronavirus_vaccine/    A,B

No change in policy. The closing of Helsinki's upper secondary schools has been extended until 31 January.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108140940/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and

Helsinki:  Upper secondary schools (general upper secondary schools and vocational education) have transferred to distance learning as of 3 December 2020. These learning institutions will still provide face-to-face instruction that is deemed essential. For example, contact teaching will be offered to students with disabilities that are receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for various reasons. Distance learning will continue at these schools until 31 January 2021.    A mask recommendation has been issued for the area’s lower secondary schools (grades 6-9). The cities will provide masks for this purpose, but students are also free to use their own.    Daycare centres and pre-primary education are still open, with due regard for the necessary safety measures. Daycare centre staff are encouraged to wear masks indoors whenever possible. Early childhood education employees who travel to several locations in their work, for example, daycare assistants, replacements, directors, trainees and interns are in particular asked to observe this mask recommendation. Parents and guardians of children in daycare and pre-primary education are asked to wear masks when they pick up and drop off their children and limit the time they spend indoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115123931/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and

Upper secondary schools (general upper secondary schools and vocational education) have transferred to distance learning as of 3 December 2020. These learning institutions will still provide face-to-face instruction that is deemed essential. For example, contact teaching will be offered to students with disabilities that are receiving special needs education and to students who need individual support for various reasons. Distance learning will continue at these schools until 31 January 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124191636/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/coronavirus-en/childhood-and

In general, working from home is recommended and workplaces remain open. In Helsinki, public spaces have been closed, which means the closure of some sectors, including all urban indoor sports facilities, cultural centers, museums, youth facilities and the zoo. This measure is in place from 30 Nov 2020 until 31 Jan 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset

Generally open across the country:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115124620/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta#accordion-UVp6uI6UjCaV    But public spaces are closed in Helsinki until 31st January:  All customer spaces open to the public will be closed. This means, for example, all urban indoor sports facilities, cultural centers, museums and youth facilities. Workers' colleges will be suspended. Korkeasaari Zoo will also close.?  Facilities for social and health services, early childhood education, basic education and basic secondary education will be kept open. Also, for example, the necessary use of transaction machines in libraries and the distribution of face masks to the needy will continue. Cities define facilities that provide essential services that are kept open in a limited and safe manner.  The coordination group recommends private actors to close the corresponding sports and leisure facilities.?  Libraries offer a limited service  Valid from 30.11.2020 to 31.01.2021.    Half of the customer seats in restaurants serving mainly alcoholic beverages may be used, 3/4 non-alcoholic restaurants. The restriction is valid on 28.2.2021. until current  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset    Teleworking is widely recommended  Teleworking is recommended for all those tasks where it is possible to do it, taking into account the work tasks. In addition, work arrangements will be promoted to reduce close contacts and other risk factors in the workplace.  In private and public sector workplaces, it is recommended that all those present present use face masks indoors at all encounters and when moving around the workplace. The use of a face mask is not required for persons who, due to their state of health, cannot use the mask. A person's own statement of the matter is considered sufficient.  The recommendation is valid until further notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset

Coding 2T due to the following:  All customer spaces open to the public will be closed. This means, for example, all indoor sports facilities, cultural houses, museums and youth facilities in cities. The work of the labour colleges will be suspended. Korkeasaari Zoo will also close.  Service centers are closed. The opening of service centres will be reviewed in February.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124192734/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset     The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health recommend working remotely to the extent possible in both the public and private sectors. This recommendation will remain in force throughout the country until further notice and will be reviewed by 30 June 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124192250/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions

The strictest regional policy is that public events and gatherings are only allowed up to 10 people, which means that, in practice, what we understand under public events are not able to take place.     This regulation is curently in force in (updated from previous notes):   Helsinki and Uusimaa, 30.11.2020-31.1.2021   Päijät-Häme, 30.11.2020-25.1.2021   Kanta-Häme, 1.12.2020-31.1.2021  Kymenlaakso, 1.12.2020-10.1.2021   Länsi-Pohja, 7.12.2020-18.1.2021   Varsinais-Suomi, 11.12.2020-10.2.2021   Pirkanmaa and Punkalaidunta: 2.12.2020-17.1.2021   Central Finland, Southern Ostrobothnia, Central Ostrobothnia and Vaasa: 22.12.2020-17.1.2021   Northern Ostrobothnia: 2.12.2020-18.1.2021     At the national level, public meetings and general meetings of more than 50 people can be organized in limited areas outdoors and indoors if the events follow the government's social distancing guidelines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108143432/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

No restrictions on private events.  Regional government agencies' regulations on restrictions on gatherings do not apply to private events, such as weddings organized by private individuals. Private events are all private events that are not open to the public, such as weddings, funerals, christenings, birthday parties, and private evenings. However, the government recommends that general guidelines on hygiene, safety distances, and other arrangements to prevent coronavirus infections be followed at these events as well.    Public events are allowed in as much as the meeting regulations allow, so those areas whereby 10 people maximum can meet (see C4) are consequentially unable to hold events. Hence 2T. In Helinki, correspondingly, all indoor and outdoor public events and general meetings are prohibited for a limited period of time, allowing up to 10 people to attend essential public events and meetings, provided that safety can be ensured in accordance with the instructions issued by the Ministry of Education and Culture and THL on 21.9.2020.?  [https://web.archive.org/web/20210108143432/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta#item-FkUhWGKAqmTQ-33782706]  https://web.archive.org/web/20210108142952/https://www.hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset

Unemployment benefit is available to salaried and self employed.  The exempt amount applicable to unemployment benefits has been raised temporarily. The exempt amount is the amount a recipient of unemployment benefits can earn without it reducing their benefits. If the benefit is paid every four weeks, you can earn a gross amount, i.e. amount before taxes, of EUR 465. If the benefit is paid on a monthly basis, you can earn EUR 500. The increase applies to benefit adjustment periods beginning between 1 June 2020 and 31 March 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124202334/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

Business Finland has introduced a new research, development and innovation loan (RDI loan). This will be available to limited companies of all sizes (limited liability companies and public limited companies) and in all sectors. The loan is intended for all companies operating in labour-intensive sectors in Finland that are suffering from business disruptions caused by the coronavirus crisis. The purpose of this loan finance is to help companies keep their employees in work during the crisis and also to encourage companies to explore opportunities for providing new jobs in Finland after the crisis is over.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124203306/https://tem.fi/en/questions-and-answers-regarding-the-coronavirus-and-business-financing
