If you get symptoms, get tested for coronavirus and otherwise stay at home. It is important that you get tested for the coronavirus even if you have only mild symptoms suitable for coronavirus infections.   Perform a symptom assessment in the Omaolo service. In some municipalities, the Omaolo symptom assessment allows you to make a test appointment or provides instructions on how to make an appointment.  Check your municipality’s website for booking instructions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124204404/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus
No change, the main means for contact tracing is a government app.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210108150759/https://koronavilkku.fi/en/

Contract Tracing is done via a mobile app rolled out by the government.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210124204732/https://koronavilkku.fi/en/     It also seems that the municipality of residence carries out contact tracing.   “The need for quarantine depends on whether you have been in close contact with a person infected with coronavirus.  When a person is diagnosed with a coronavirus infection, the municipality of residence carries out contract tracing, on the basis of which nearby contacts are quarantined. If a person is not considered a close contact, they can continue their life as normal.  Contact tracing can take some time, especially if there are many exposed persons. If you do not know what to do, contact health care to check the situation.”\  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124205141/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/quarantine-and-isolation     While the mobile app provides one means to reach contacts, the more traditional human resources have been responsible for most of contact tracing. Further resources have gained by training existing and new personnel for this task. In September about 3000 persons registered to online free contact tracing course by THL, Tampere University and University of Eastern Finland and over 1000 already completed the course. On 14th of October THL started gathering contact information of individuals, organisations and communities outside of public sector interested in participating in contact-tracing carried out by hospital districts and municipalities. By forwarding contacts THL aims to assist hospital districts and municipalities in recruitment of personnel for contact tracing.(20)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124205609/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/finland/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.4+Monitoring+and+surveillance&Type=Section

Mask use is never mandatory, but now recommended extensively. In the regions where the infection rates are highest, in the so-called "spreading phase" (according to the Finnish classification of regions into 3 types: basic, accelleration, spreading), the recommendation includes:   - Always on public transport including taxis.  - Always in public spaces and events, including schools and educational institutions from year 7 upwards.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108154838/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

Recommended for the use of a face mask for all people over 15 years of age  In public transport  In public events and facilities such as shops and banks  In city services such as libraries, social and health services, and cultural services  At sports and cultural events  In all leisure facilities  In secondary schools, including high schools, and colleges  In high schools. For high school students, the city offers masks.  Parents in early childhood education facilities, for example when taking and picking up children  For early childhood education staff indoors where possible. The use of the mask is especially recommended for people who travel to different places in their work, such as deputies, daycare assistants, daycare managers, interns and on-the-job learners.  Social and health care personnel in patient and client work  In the workplace for all those present at all encounters and when moving around the workplace. The recommendation applies to both private and public sector jobs.  When applying for a coronavirus test and before obtaining a result, if there is a necessary reason to move outdoors  When arriving in Finland from a risk area and moving from the point of entry to quarantine or if there is a necessary reason to move outside during quarantine.  In other situations where it is not possible to avoid close contact.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201127004315/https://hel.fi/helsinki/korona-fi/koronaneuvonta/voimassa-olevat-suositukset-ja-rajoitukset#matkustus

THL currently recommends the use of face masks in all parts of the country. A,B,C as per: https://web.archive.org/web/20210115143227/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19 Vaccines on order: BioNTech – Pfizer (Comirnaty-vaccin) Moderna AstraZeneca Curevac Jansen Group Sanofi-GSK Novavax http://web.archive.org/web/20210115143749/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/vaccines-and-coronavirus/arranging-covid-19-vaccinations-in-finland  Note, that all are planned to be vaccinated, but it is currently only rolled out for two groups: According to a Government Decree (22 December 2020), the vaccinations are first offered to social and health care professionals who treat COVID-19 patients and to people who work and live in nursing homes or housing services for the elderly. Most of these vaccinations will be carried out in January–February 2021.   The vaccine will then be offered to elderly persons and to those with diseases that predispose them to severe coronavirus disease. After that, the vaccine will be offered to the rest of the population. It is still unclear when the vaccine can be offered to everyone willing to be vaccinated because the schedule mainly depends on the marketing authorisations and the availability of the vaccines.

La capacité de dépistage dans les établissements scolaires sera également augmentée, avec un objectif de 300 000 tests par semaine et des objectifs fixés par académie.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115103746/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Testing freely available for asymptomatic people who are at particular risk from the disease.  La vaccination est désormais ouverte à l’ensemble des personnes appartenant aux catégories suivantes :  •	Les personnes âgées de plus de 75 ans (à partir de lundi 18 janvier).  •	Les résidents volontaires en EHPAD et USLD, qui sont vaccinés directement dans les établissements.  •	Les personnes âgées séjournant dans les établissements de santé et en services de soins de suite et de réadaptation.  •	Les personnes âgées hébergées en résidences autonomie, résidences services et autres lieux de vie spécialisés, ainsi que dans les foyers de travailleurs migrants.  •	Les personnes en situation de handicap, vulnérables, hébergées en maisons d’accueil spécialisées et foyers d’accueils médicalisés.  •	Les professionnels de santé (et autres professionnels des établissements de santé et des établissements médico-sociaux intervenant auprès de personnes vulnérables), les aides à domicile intervenant auprès de personnes âgées et handicapées vulnérables et les sapeurs-pompiers, lorsqu’ils ont plus de 50 ans ou présentent une ou plusieurs des comorbidités suivantes :  o	L’obésité (IMC>30),  o	La BPCO et l’insuffisance respiratoire,  o	L’hypertension artérielle compliquée,  o	L’insuffisance cardiaque,  o	Le diabète (de type 1 et de type 2)  o	L’insuffisance rénale chronique,  o	Les cancers et maladies hématologiques malignes actifs et de moins de 3 ans  o	Le fait d’avoir une transplantation d’organe solide ou de cellules souches hématopoïétiques,  o	La trisomie 21.  •	Les personnes ayant une pathologie qui les expose à un très haut risque face à la Covid-19 disposant d’une ordonnance médicale pour se faire vacciner prioritairement.  Les patients particulièrement vulnérables à la Covid concernés sont les suivants :  o	atteints de cancer et de maladies hématologiques malignes en cours de traitement par chimiothérapie  o	atteints de maladies rénales chroniques sévères, dont les patients dialysés  o	transplantés d’organes solides  o	transplantés par allogreffe de cellules souches hématopoïétiques  o	atteints de poly-pathologies chroniques, selon le critère suivant : au moins deux insuffisances d’organes  o	atteints de certaines maladies rares (voire liste sur le site du ministère de la santé)  o	atteints de trisomie 21.  Si vous êtes concerné, vous pouvez vous faire vacciner dès à présent dans un des centres de vaccination ouverts.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115113356/https://www.sante.fr/centres-vaccination-covid.html    Testing for people who do not meet these criteria is also available, but at a cost of about EUR 70 to EUR 100. Which however is covered by French Health insurance (“Sécurité Sociale”). So e.g. a US citizen who is not covered by French Health insurance would have to pay for the treatment individually.  https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Further confirmation that testing without symptoms is available (need to get an appointment via a website), but people who do not meet the above mentioned criteria are not considered a priority (implying it may take longer for them to get an appointment).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115121550/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

A, C:    The HAS (Haute Autorite de Sante = High Authority of Health) recommends first vaccinating the elderly in establishments, in particular EHPADs, as well as the staff working there when they are at risk of developing a severe form of COVID. This represents around 1 million people.    On January 5, 2020, Olivier Véran indicated that firefighters and home helpers over 50 years old will be able to benefit from the injection as priority personnel. "They are also professionals who are in contact with fragile people and who may have to work with the sick," said the minister to justify this decision.  https://archive.vn/a0Ju1

A, C:    Previously coded policy is still in place in this period. By now, 318.216 have been vaccinated, out of which 10% are residents of care homes. The remainder are caregivers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities, but also firefighters, home helpers over the age of 50 or with comorbidities.  https://archive.vn/J7Rwn    So some members of the following groups have started receiving vaccines:  A Key workers  C Elderly groups  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    The vaccines that are given are PfizerBiontech and Moderna.  BioNTech-Pfizer's vaccine was approved by the EMA and then by the European Commission on 22 December. On Wednesday 6 January 2021, the European Commission gave the green light to the Covid-19 vaccine developed by the American start-up Moderna, this decision was approved by the High Health Authority on Friday 8 January 2021. To date, two additional vaccines are being evaluated by the EMA following Phase III clinical trials: the AstraZeneca and Janssen laboratories.  https://archive.vn/dNmaS    In addition, from 18 January, people over the age of 75 will be able to get vaccinated as well as people with one of the five pathologies leading to a very high risk of serious form of the disease, regardless of their age.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210113222447/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins    Note that the government has faced a lot of criticism regarding a perceived slowness and overly bureaucratic approach in rolling out the vaccines.  https://archive.vn/R3Ic2    France wants to immunize 1 million people by the end of January but at the current vaccination rate, it will reach that target in late February.  There is also widespread vaccine-scepticism.  https://archive.vn/trhlh    Polls suggest that less than 40% of the population here is planning to take the vaccine.   https://archive.vn/J7Rwn
A, C:    As of Jan 24, 1,092,958 people received the first dose of Covid-19 vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126170527/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

As a consequence of the pandemic and the current infection rates internationally, the Danish government has decided to place the entire world on the travel red list. This means that the authorities are discouraging all international travel, included work-related travel. Denmark has therefore introduced stricter requirements to travellers who travel to Denmark and do not have a residence there. In Northern Ireland:    Schools are to remain closed for an extended period as the Stormont executive agreed new measures this evening to tackle the spread of Covid-19.    Deputy First Minister Michelle O'Neill said pupils will not be returning to classrooms on Monday January 11 as was originally intended.    Northern Ireland's 3 universities- Queen's Belfast, Ulster, and St Mary's seem to have closed campuses- see Queen's twitter post with FAQs for 'when to return to campus', indicating this is not yet occurring.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210106133036/https://www.irishnews.com/news/northernirelandnews/2021/01/04/news/covid-19-schools-closed-for-extended-period-as-northern-ireland-in-dire-situation--2177581/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106133241/https://www.nidirect.gov.uk/articles/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-schools-colleges-and-universities    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106134210/https://twitter.com/QUBelfast/status/1346562116497649664      In England: government guidance for universities is: 'Universities- Those students who are undertaking training and study for the specific courses should return to face to face learning as planned and be tested twice, upon arrival or self-isolate for ten days https://web.archive.org/web/20210106100514/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/national-lockdown-stay-at-home'. As our codebook describes, the C1 indicator records closing of schools and universities, so this does not close universities, and therefore does not warrant a 3 code.

Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020. All devolved nations are under stay at home orders    Scots are to be ordered to stay at home amid a fresh Covid-19 lockdown on 5 January. These are the toughest restrictions Scotland has faced since the lockdown of March 2020.      The new rules - which will be put down in law - mean Scots will only be allowed to leave home for essential purposes, such as shopping for food and medicine, exercise and caring responsibilities.    No limit is to be put on how many times people can go out to exercise, but outdoor meetings are to be limited to a maximum of two people from two households.      These rules will apply across the Scottish mainland until at least the end of January, and will be kept under review.    https://web.archive.org/web/20

The government has quietly introduced a loophole to its eviction ban that waters down protections for people who lost their jobs during the pandemic.    Ministers on Friday announced that they were extending the ban on bailiff evictions that has been in place since the first lockdown in March, covering most tenants for another six weeks.    But the announcement did not mention a key change snuck out in legislation that will for the first time give landlords the power to evict people for not paying their rent during lockdown.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210115172832/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/eviction-ban-loophole-substantial-arrears-six-months-b1784836.html

No policy change    As of 29 January, entry into the country remains suspended for most foreign citizens. This entry ban for foreign citizens applies to air, land, and sea borders. The entry ban includes foreign citizens who are legal residents of Georgia, or have been living and working in Georgia, or own property or business (without special status).     Exceptions to the entry ban on foreign citizens currently include: the spouse or minor child (under 18) of a Georgian citizen and citizens and/or legal residents of certain EU countries.    The following travelers may apply for special permission to enter Georgia by following the instructions on the Government of Georgia’s website: Certain business travelers, citizens and/or legal residents of five EU countries (Germany, France, Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia), certain foreign citizens who seek to enter Georgia for a long-term visit of at least 6 months to work as a freelancer or as self-employed, and students.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130011411/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

On 21 January, the national action plan for vaccination was approved. The plan seeks to make sure that 60% of the population are vaccinated by the end of 2021. According to the plan, the highest-risk target groups will be vaccinated first.    Only those vaccines that enjoy authorization from the World Health Organization will be imported into the country, stated Georgian Prime Minister Giorgi Gakharia.    "As you know, at the previous Cabinet meeting, the Health Ministry was instructed to finalize the national action plan for vaccination, to make sure that it is approved by today's Cabinet meeting. The relevant working group was created on December 15 to bring together all stakeholders, including experts, international partners, field specialists, epidemiologists, doctors, the Public Defender, and others," Giorgi Gakharia said.    "Alongside its key goal, equally important is the plan's technical aspect, including timeframe and target groups to vaccinated in stages according to this timeframe. Allow me to emphasize that the highest-risk target groups will be vaccinated at the initial stage, meaning medical personnel, long-term care facility residents, our senior citizens aged 75 and over, and then all our citizens aged between 65 and 75," Giorgi Gakharia stated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130050759/https://stopcov.ge/en/News/Article/Prime_Minister%E2%80%99s_Statements_at_Cabinet_Meeting

Jutarnji List reports that classes in Croatia, except those affected by the earthquake-affected Sisak-Moslavina County, should likely resume in schools on January 18. “We sincerely hope that the trend with small numbers of infected students will continue so that we can start the second semester with as many children in schools as possible,” said the advisor to the Minister of Education Božo Pavicin.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110150155/https://www.total-croatia-news.com/news/49522-students-in-croatia
No policy change. Students to return to school on 18 January. (except Sisak-Moslavina County)

Policy update: continue to restrict non-mandatory arrivals to Croatia. On January 13, the new border rules for entry were announced (read more about them here). On January 15, the rules are further explained, and the biggest change is that travelers arriving in Croatia from the United Kingdom and the South African Republic need to have a negative PCR test AND they need to self-isolate for 14 days (or have their self-isolation shortened if they pay for another test, at least 7 days after they've entered Croatia), no matter what their citizenship is.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117124536/https://www.koronavirus.hr/recommendations-and-instructions-for-crossing-the-state-border/736  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117131401/https://www.total-croatia-news.com/travel/43707-croatia-corona-travel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117131726/https://www.total-croatia-news.com/travel/49647-new-border-rules-for-croatia

The government announced that from midnight on 24 December until 12 January, Level 5 restrictions (the equivalent of full lockdown) will apply nationally, due to NPHET concerns at the rapid increase in COVID-19 case numbers.    Under normal level 5 restrictions, schools remain open, but the decision was made on 30th December to delay reopening schools for the new term. On the 6th January, it was decided to close all schools, including for students with special needs, for at least three weeks.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201230203846/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/education/schools-welcome-decision-to-close-until-january-11th-1.4447636  http://web.archive.org/web/20210107211029/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/11176-minister-foley-confirms-that-schools-will-remain-closed-to-students/

"Schools    Schools are currently closed for all students with remote learning in place.    Youthreach services will resume as scheduled.    The resumption of the Early Childhood Care and Education (ECCE) programme is delayed until 1 February.    Higher and adult education    Higher, further and adult education should remain primarily online."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210110221430/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/
No change recorded.
** No change in policy. Ireland is on Level 5 until 31 January 2021. **

** No change in policy. Ireland is on Level 5 until 31 January 2021. **    Schools are currently closed for all students with remote learning in place.    Youthreach services will resume as scheduled.    The resumption of the Early Childhood Care and Education (ECCE) programme is delayed until 1 February.    Higher and adult education    Higher, further and adult education should remain primarily online."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210110221430/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/2dc71-level-5/

On 22 December the Taoiseach announced the introduction of level 5 restrictions (full lockdown) though with temporary relaxations for the Christmas period (24 to 26 December inclusive).     Retail stores were thus allowed to remain open.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201222133641/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/a1f21-ireland-placed-on-level-5-restrictions-of-the-plan-for-living-with-covid-19-with-a-number-of-specific-adjustments/
Level 5 restrictions (full lockdown) in effect.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210112174352/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ireland/coronavirus

"Ireland is on Level 5 until 31 January 2021."    "Restaurants, cafes and pubs that serve food can open for take away services only. Wet pubs remain closed.    Hotels and other accomodation can open only for essential purposes.    All non-essential shops are closed. Click and collect services are suspended.    All other personal services, such as hairdressers, beauticians and barbers, must close."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210113181643/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html
No change recorded.

From 9 January 2021, all passengers arriving at Irish airports and ports whose journey originates in Great Britain or South Africa will be requested to have evidence of a negative result from a pre-departure PCR COVID-19 test (COVID-19 not detected) taken up to 72 hours prior to arrival in Ireland.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210112174352/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ireland/coronavirus

Effective from 16 January 2021, all passengers arriving into Ireland (except those arriving from Northern Ireland) are required to have a negative or ‘not detected’ result from a pre-departure COVID-19 RT-PCR test that was carried out no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Ireland.  https://archive.vn/jGJsl

"On 26 January the Government announced the introduction of additional, short-term restrictions. These will include mandatory quarantine measures applying to all international arrivals and the suspension of visa-free travel to Ireland (with limited exemptions) for nationals of South Africa and all countries in South America."     http://web.archive.org/web/20210128095739/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/coronavirus/general-covid-19-travel-advisory/

A double rate of Covid Restrictions Support Scheme (CRSS) will be paid for two weeks to businesses that are forced to close as a direct result of government restrictions on 26 December.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201222133641/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/a1f21-ireland-placed-on-level-5-restrictions-of-the-plan-for-living-with-covid-19-with-a-number-of-specific-adjustments/
No change recorded.

No change in policy. Measures announced in the 2021 Budget to support business and workers remain in effect.    €3.2 billion to support people through the COVID Pandemic Unemployment Payment (PUP) and the Employment Wage Subsidy Scheme (EWSS)  €100 million to support businesses affected by COVID-19.  https://archive.vn/V6XBh

** No change recorded. Income support still in effect. **    The Irish Government announced additional flexibility for self-employed workers on the scheme was announced. Self-employed people in receipt of the PUP who are looking to restart their business can now earn up to €960 over an 8 week period, while retaining their full PUP entitlement. This is an increase from the €480 previously allowed over a 4 week period and comes following engagement across a number of sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201214193900/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/43e6e-briefing-on-the-governments-response-to-covid-19-friday-11-december-2020/

A, C:    Iceland received the first doses of COVID-19 vaccine on December 28 and vaccination began on December 29. At the moment, Iceland is expecting to receive vaccine for at least 30,000 people before the end of March.  COVID-19 vaccination is optional and free of charge in Iceland. Vaccines are being administered according to priority groups defined by health authorities, though the Chief Epidemiologist may grant exceptions to that order. The first to be vaccinated were frontline healthcare workers and nursing home residents. According to the current vaccination schedule, the next priority groups are people over the age of 70, paramedics who transport COVID-19 patients, and some additional healthcare workers        https://web.archive.org/web/20210106190138/https://www.icelandreview.com/ask-ir/whats-the-status-of-covid-19-vaccination-in-iceland/      http://web.archive.org/web/20210103140447/https://www.covid.is/categories/information-on-covid-19-vaccine

No change in previous policy:    State and municipal institutions and bodies and state and municipal enterprises and the private sector will organise work and provide customer services remotely, except where relevant functions (work) have to be performed at the workplace, while ensuring conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations for the management of the flow of people, safe physical distance, and other key requirements for public health safety, hygiene, and the provision of persons with necessary personal protective equipment    Stores, including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres, marketplaces and other public points of sale will be closed except:    -stores (including those in shopping and/or entertainment centres), whose main business is the retail of food, veterinary, animal feed, pharmacy, optical goods and orthopedic technical devices;  -selling food in marketplaces and public points of sale;  -remote commerce (by internet or other means of communication), where goods are delivered to natural and legal persons or collected at collection points;  -funeral stores;  -outdoor trade in Christmas trees and other festive trees.    Stores that remain open will be required to:    ensure 15 sq. m. of retail space per visitor or serve only one visitor at a time and ensure other conditions laid down by the State Commander of National Emergency Operations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021
Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

There will be no indoor or outdoor commercial or non-commercial cultural, entertainment, sporting events, celebrations, fairs, festivals or other mass gatherings arranged in public locations of a certain duration at a scheduled time except:    -high-performance sporting events without spectators;  -funerals attended by maximum 10 persons except family and/or household members and persons providing funeral services.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021
Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

It is allowed to be in public places in groups of no more than 2 persons or in groups of one family and/or one household.    It is prohibited:    -to have close contacts between members of more than one family and/or one household except:  emergencies, where it is necessary to provide assistance;  attending to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves;    -to hold private parties in public and private venues with the participation of more than one family and/or household.     Transport vehicles other than regular public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) or transport vehicles to commute to work may carry groups of no more than 2 persons or groups of members of one family and/or one household. When providing passenger transportation service for a fare by a passenger car on call and by a taxi passenger car, the driver of the vehicle will not be counted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

No change to previous policy:    Passengers travelling by public transport (city, long-distance and suburban) will be required to travel seated maintaining the distance of at least one meter between each other. It is required to stay at home except:    to go to work (for work purposes);  to go shopping;  to go to/from airports, seaports, bus stations serving international passenger routes;  to go to your real estate property;  to go to a funeral;  for health and other essential services;  for other essential services or for objectively justified reasons where it is absolutely necessary;  to go for a walk in open spaces only with members of your family or household;  to attend to the sick or to those unable to take care of themselves.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

People returning / arriving from affected countries are subjects to 10-day isolation. Isolation does not apply to those who have a negative test for COVID-19 performed not earlier than 48 hours ago.    You can also be tested in Lithuania. In this case, isolation applies to you until a negative laboratory test is obtained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107143201/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad

Protective face masks are mandatory in all public places (for all from the age of 6). Exceptions will apply in the following cases:     exercising individuals;  high-performance sports training;  during the provision of a service where a service cannot be provided when a customer is wearing a mask;  persons with disability who cannot wear a mask due to their health condition or where it can adversely affect their health condition. They are recommended to wear a face shield instead.  when outside populated areas (cities, towns, villages, single-homestead settlements and dacha (garden) settlements) and when there are no other people within the radius of 20 metres, except for family members;  children over the age of 6 who are educated under pre-school, pre-primary and primary education programmes will not be required to wear protective equipment covering nose and mouth (face masks, respirators or other equipment) while in education establishments and/or their territories.  Face masks are mandatory in common areas.    It is recommended to wear a face mask at a private party, if held, or when socialising with members of other families /households.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103153704/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-3-january-2021

A:    Lithuania started vaccinations against COVID-19 on 27th of December:    "Lithuania on Saturday started to vaccinate its medical workers against the coronavirus in a coordinated push by the European Union against the global pandemic.  Nijole Ramonaite, a nurse at Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos, was the first person in the country inoculated by the vaccine produced by Pfizer and BionTech.  Vaccination was launched in hospitals in Vilnius, Kaunas, Klaipeda, Siauliai and Panevezys simultaneously at 8:00 a.m. on Sunday."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154724/https://www.baltictimes.com/lithuania_starts_vaccinations_against_covid-19/    Regarding strategy:  Acting Health Minister Aurelijus Veryga said that medics and at-risk people in the country would be vaccinated from the coronavirus first. If a sufficient amount of vaccines is delivered to Lithuania, mass vaccination of the population could start in February or March, according to Veryga.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228154743/https://www.lrt.lt/en/news-in-english/19/1296189/most-people-in-lithuania-to-receive-vaccines-by-mid-summer-says-president

A, B:     The first doses of the vaccine will be given for the medical staff working in the COVID-19 wards, emergency departments, and those at high risk for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107161149/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/lithuanian-healthcare-workers-start-getting-the-covid-19-vaccine

If you present symptoms potentially related to COVID-19, directly consult your doctor for a test on medical prescription.    The Luxembourg government is embarking on a new phase of screening with the aim to test representative samples of the population in order to monitor developments and to be as flexible as possible in the event of an increase in the number of cases. Appointments for this large scale screening is by invitation only so coding remains at 2.    Link - https://web.archive.org/web/20210105161043/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing.html

The person who tested positive is asked to provide the Health Inspectorate with the contact details of all close contacts they have had in the days prior to the test or before the onset of symptoms.    Quarantine applies to people who have had high-risk contact with a person with a confirmed infection, i.e. face-to-face contact for more than 15 minutes, unprotected physical contact, etc. These people must stay at home for 7 days counting from the day of the last contact with the infected person. During the 7 days following the quarantine, they must self-monitor and wear a mask when in contact with other people. If any symptoms appear, they must immediately be tested again and placed in isolation; failure to do so incurs a fine.    Self-monitoring lasts 14 days. It applies to people who have had low-risk contact with a person who has been confirmed as being infected. People who are self-monitoring take their temperature twice a day and check that they have no respiratory problems or cough and are able to continue with their normal activities.    Link - https://web.archive.org/web/20210105162109/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/isolation-quarantine-treatment.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210105162120/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/contact-transmission.html

- in all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  - for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210105163404/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html

The first people to be vaccinated are health professionals and staff in hospitals, as well as ambulance drivers, staff in residential care facilities for the elderly and in care and support networks, and people living in these facilities. On Thursday 28 and 29 December, around 800 people from the hospital sector will be vaccinated, and 200 people per hospital establishment for acute treatments respectively. On Wednesday 30 December, staff from senior citizens' homes will be vaccinated - with an additional 400 vaccinations planned. In addition, paramedics transporting COVID-19 patients were offered vaccination during these three days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210103233531/https://gouvernement.lu/en/actualites/toutes_actualites/communiques/2020/12-decembre/28-vaccin-covid.html

On Tuesday, 29 December, The Cabinet of Ministers agreed on a “holiday curfew”, stipulating that all residents of Latvia from 30 December to 4 January, as well as on 8 and 9 January from 22.00 to 5.00, must stay at their place of residence. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. Consequently, sales and service outlets will be open from 6.00 to 21.00, so that employees can get from home to work and back without breaking the rules.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew

No specific measures implemented. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. The clarifications in the security measures for the holiday season approved by the Cabinet of Ministers do not restrict freedom of movement. Public transport will continue to run and people are encouraged to take the opportunity to spend time outdoors in nature.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew

It is allowed to enter Latvia, provided that the guidelines developed by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (SPKC) are being followed. When arriving from countries with a 14-day cumulative number of COVID-19 cases that is higher than 50 per 100,000 inhabitants, self-isolation must be observed for 10 days.  10-day self-isolation must be observed when entering Latvia from the countries listed in the “National COVID-19 morbidity rates” section of the SPKC website.  If a person is arriving from a “safe” country by transiting through an “unsafe country”, the person must observe self-isolation; in order to avoid self-isolation, a different return route must be chosen.  Self-isolation means staying in the place of self-isolation without exposing other persons to the risk of infection and without making direct contact with others (not receiving guests, not visiting anyone, not going to work or public places where many people may be present, except for going to the shop or getting to the place of residence or of self-isolation immediately after arriving in Latvia, using a mouth and nose covering).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207042737/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/covid-19-frequently-asked-questions-and-answers

On January 7, the government adopted stricter regulations for all people entering the country to facilitate more epidemiologically safe movement and reduce the introduction of COVID-19 infection into the country. When entering Latvia both with passenger transport and a personal vehicle, one must present confirmation of a negative COVID-19 test result. The regulations will take effect on January 15.  One must undergo the test not earlier than 72 hours before boarding a carrier’s vehicle or before crossing the Latvian border individually, for example, by road. The condition on 10 days of self-isolation and other epidemiological safety instructions provided by the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control of Latvia must be followed after entry from abroad with a high risk of infection remains unchanged.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210118233812/https://www.mk.gov.lv/en/article/entering-latvia-will-be-possible-only-presenting-negative-covid-19-test-january-15

A:    The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service.     It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

A:    The first vaccination rooms in Latvia started operating on December 28, 2020. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) and the European Commission (EC) have approved the quality, safety and efficacy of the first two Covid-19 vaccines. These are the vaccine Comirnaty manufactured by Pfizer-BioNTech and the vaccine manufactured by Moderna.      The vaccine will first be given to medical staff working with Covid-19 patients and to the staff of the Emergency Medical Service (EMS). After that, other vaccines will be gradually delivered to Latvia. The first vaccines will be given to healthcare workers working with Covid-19 patients in hospitals and to the Emergency Medical Service.     It is planned that all other residents of Latvia will be able to be vaccinated starting from the second quarter of 2021.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233236/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/vaccine  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111233533/https://www.spkc.gov.lv/lv/kad-vakcinas-bus-pieejamas-latvija

Educational establishments are open with masks mandatory from primary school upwards.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020.     Restaurants will be open only for lunch. Access to restaurants will be limited solely to residents of Monaco and those who work in the country Distance of at least 1.5 metres between restaurant tables (instead of 1 metre).  Bars are closed (the State is funding strengthened provisions for total temporary layoff at a rate of 100%), except for hotel bars which can remain open until 10 pm for hotel residents.    Takeaway sales will be forbidden after 7 pm. Deliveries are permitted until 9 pm.      Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
Teleworking is strongly recommended in the public and private sector.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
No policy change.

Restaurants will be open only for lunch. Access to restaurants will be limited solely to residents of Monaco and those who work in the country. Public services remain open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020. Curfew increased from 7 pm to 6 am. Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Imposition of a curfew from 7 pm to 6 am. Exemptions will apply to the curfew, primarily for work, health, and family reasons, or for brief outings with pets.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

The person will be subject to a quarantine measure taken by the Director of Health Action. This quarantine can be avoided if the person justifies carrying out a PCR with negative result or, provided that the person is asymptomatic, carrying out an antigen test with negative result, (at most 72 hours before his arrival) carried out in his country of origin.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126123518/https://covid19.mc/en/i-come-from-abroad/

Further tightening of measures, effective on 11th of January 2020. Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces    Children aged under five years and people who are exercising outdoors do not need to wear a mask. Those exercising should carry a mask in their pocket in case they need to put it on, however.  The wearing of masks in private spaces is strongly recommended, particularly when someone from outside the household or a vulnerable person is present.    Otherwise, current measures continue to apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

"Initially, vaccinations will be available to senior residents aged 75 or over, living either in care homes or in the community, who have received a letter from the Government inviting them to contact the COVID-19 Call Centre"    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115170152/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/First-COVID-19-vaccination-in-Principality    In general:    Vaccines will become available gradually, and so the Prince’s Government has had to establish priorities to ensure that at-risk groups are at the front of the queue. These groups are:    -Elderly people living in care settings    -People aged over 75    -People aged 65–74    -People with underlying health conditions (obesity (BMI>30), particularly among younger people, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory disease, complex high blood pressure disorders, heart disease, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, recent history of cancer (within the last three years), solid organ transplant or haematopoietic stem cell transplant, Down’s syndrome, etc.)    -Healthcare workers, etcA    The vaccination campaign will therefore be rolled out in several phases to target each category of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115165719/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/vaccination-procedure/

B - Thursday 31 December marks the date the very first Covid-19 vaccine was administered in Monaco. In the three weeks that followed, care home residents and the over 75s were the top priority groups to receive the dose. Vaccines were administered on a first come first serve basis.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210120170536/https://www.monaco-tribune.com/en/2021/01/covid-19-the-latest-on-monacos-vaccination-campaign/

Until January 17th, primary and secondary schools, schools for secondary vocation education (MBO) and higher education institutions (universities and HBO) will deliver teaching online in order to reduce in-person contact. Childcare centres will also be closed. Primary schools and childcare centres will remain open for children whose parents work in critical sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

No major policy changes.  Policy: "Educational institutions will provide most teaching remotely until at least 7 February. Daycare and out-of-school care centres will remain closed during this period.  Secondary schools can offer practical training, school exams for pupils in the upper years and lessons for pupils with upcoming final exams on site.  Secondary vocational schools (MBO), higher professional education institutions (HBO) and universities can offer exams and practical training on site.  All educational institutions can make exceptions to provide support to vulnerable children or students."  Source:   /web/20210130111925/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/01/20/lockdown-measures-tightened-in-response-to-concerns-about-new-variants-of-virus

People should therefore continue to work from home, unless it is absolutely necessary that they go into work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

No policy update. Current policy: Source: "Work from home. Only people whose presence is essential to operational processes and who cannot do their work from home can go to work." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130111925/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/01/20/lockdown-measures-tightened-in-response-to-concerns-about-new-variants-of-virus

Venues such as museums, theatres, amusement parks, zoos, casinos, saunas, indoor sporting venues, and establishments serving food and drink (including in hotels) will be closed throughout this period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people
No update.   All locales for public events are closed and private gatherings are highly restricted. See C4.

The government is also advising people to receive no more than 2 people aged 13 or over at home per day. Outside, the maximum group size is 2 people, including during the festive period.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Policy: "On the basis of the OMT’s advice, the government has introduced further restrictions on the number of people permitted to attend a funeral. From Monday 25 January 2021, the maximum number of people permitted will be 50.  Receive no more than 1 person aged 13 or over at your home per day.  Visit no more than 1 other household per day.  Only go outside with members of your household, on your own or with 1 other person.    Source:   /web/20210130111925/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/01/20/lockdown-measures-tightened-in-response-to-concerns-about-new-variants-of-virus

Public transport recommended for essential purposes only; however, it is still open.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

From the government's page: "Stay at home as much as possible, including during the festive season."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Stay at home recommended, no traveling.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Do not book any foreign travel until mid-March at the earliest and do not travel abroad.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112022608/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/news/2020/12/14/lockdown-in-order-to-minimise-contact-between-people

Policy: "Every journey a person makes increases the chance of causing more infections or of bringing new variants of coronavirus into the Netherlands. For this reason, the government has issued a strict travel advisory: do not travel abroad and do not book any trips abroad in the period up to and including 31 March 2021.  The government is introducing extra measures to prevent new variants of the virus being imported via travellers and to further restrict the number of travel movements. A ban on flights from the United Kingdom and a docking ban for ferries from the United Kingdom is in force. A flight ban is also in force for passenger flights from the following other countries: Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, South Africa, Suriname, Uruguay and Venezuela. At present the flight ban is expected to remain in force for one month, or until planned legislation on mandatory quarantine rules for travellers is in place."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130111925/https://www.government.nl/latest/news/2021/01/20/lockdown-measures-tightened-in-response-to-concerns-about-new-variants-of-virus

Extensive support packages in place for workers    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106121236/https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/coronavirus-financiele-regelingen/overzicht-financiele-regelingen

Two of the temporary measures are the Temporary emergency scheme for job retention (NOW) and the Temporary self-employment income support and loan scheme (TOZO).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123175030/https://business.gov.nl/corona/overview/the-coronavirus-and-your-company/

No update.   Policy: "NOW3: Employers with more than 20% turnover loss can apply for the Temporary Emergency Bridging Measure for Sustained Employment (NOW,Tijdelijke Noodmaatregel Overbrugging voor Werkbehoud) to receive compensation of their employees' wages from October 2020 - July 2021. NOW1 and NOW2 are now closed. NOW 3 is divided into three periods: NOW 3.1 compensates wages from 1 October 2020 until 1 January 2021. NOW 3.2 runs from 1 January until 1 April, and NOW 3.3 from 1 April until 1 July 2021."  Source:   /web/20210130122719/https://business.gov.nl/subsidy/corona-crisis-temporary-emergency-measure-now/

Through government websites, social media, media/news outlets, etc. Downloadable pamphlets available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test
No change.  Source: /web/20210130124725/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

If you have (mild) symptoms of COVID-19, make an appointment to get tested. People who do not have symptoms can only get tested if one or both of the following apply: Contact tracing has shown they have been in close contact with an infected person. They have received a notification from the CoronaMelder app following contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

No policy change.  Policy: "If you have (mild) symptoms of COVID-19, make an appointment to get tested.    People who do not have symptoms can only get tested if one or both of the following apply:    Contact tracing has shown they have been in close contact with an infected person.  They have received a notification from the CoronaMelder app following contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus."    Source: /web/20210130124725/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

CoronaMelder app put in place for tracing and contacting potentially infected peoples.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112024324/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

No update.  Policy: "Contact tracing means working out where you may have contracted the infection (the source). The GGD also looks at who you have been in contact with (PDF, 210 KB), and who you may have infected (your contacts). The purpose of contact tracing is to prevent the virus from spreading further. You and your contacts will be given specific instructions on what to do. You and family members or other people that you live with must in any case stay at home. The GGD will explain what this means. It is important that you inform your GP, employer and/or company doctor of the results of the test."  Source:  /web/20210130124725/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-test

Everyone aged 13 or over is required to wear a face mask for general use in the following situations: In buildings and covered spaces that are accessible to the public (in so far as these are open). Both customers and staff should wear a face mask in locations where contact-based professions are carried out. On public transport, in stations, on platforms and at bus and tram stops.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210112025205/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/tackling-new-coronavirus-in-the-netherlands/basic-rules-for-everyone

No change in policy: "From 1 December 2020 face masks must be work in all indoor public spaces and covered areas. This includes educational institutions, public transport and locations where contact-based professions are carried out, as well as shops, town halls and train stations. Make sure the mask covers your nose, mouth and chin."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130131217/https://www.government.nl/topics/coronavirus-covid-19/face-masks-mandatory-in-all-indoor-public-spaces  ***Updated to provide working link

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Schools and education  All teaching and planned events at universities, university colleges and vocational training schools will take place digitally until 18 January. (New)  All upper and lower secondary schools in Norway will switch to a red level of alert. (New)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

All teaching and planned events at universities, university colleges and vocational training schools will take place digitally until 19 January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114092405/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-january-2021/id2826828/

Primary and secondary schools are open with covid measures in place.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210126104143/https://www.helsenorge.no/koronavirus/barnehager-og-skoler/    Universities are closed: "All universities, university colleges and vocational schools should use digital instruction where this is possible. All planned events should be digital and larger lectures and gatherings should be avoided. Students in areas without high rates of infection should have the option of in-person instruction at least once a week where it is possible to implement smaller groups and in accordance with infection control guidelines."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126101741/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-20-january-2021/id2826828/

On 23 January, after an outbreak of the more contagious "British" coronavirus variant, Oslo and nine neighbouring municipalities have switched from the 'yellow' to the 'red' level according to the country's 3-level traffic light system. For schools, this means that municipalities may decide to close the schools and kindergartens if it is necessary to prepare for the red level or if the infection situation requires.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210126104250/https://www.thelocal.no/20210123/norway-imposes-tough-lockdown-after-outbreak    Thus far, Oslo's primary schools have remained open and secondary schools have switched to distance learning. That means that country-wide universities are closed but other schools open, and at the municipal level in Oslo the situation is stricter with universities as well as secondary schools being closed, but since primary schools remain open this does not change the code to 3T.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210126104811/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/barnehager-og-skoler/

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  At the national level:  • Working from home is advised for everybody who is able to do so.  • Shops remain open, but all shopping centres and shops must introduce limits on the number of customers permitted inside to enable distancing and to control access to the premises.  • Restaurants and bars remain open, but with a ban on alcohol sales in place.     The restrictions are stricter in Oslo, where people are not recommended but required to work from home if possible, but shops and restaurants remain open. Cinemas, theatres, playgrounds, gyms, sports and swimming pools are closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

On 23 January, after an outbreak of the more contagious "British" coronavirus variant, Oslo and nine neighbouring municipalities have switched from the 'yellow' to the 'red' level according to the country's 3-level traffic light system. This includes the closing of all but essential businesses, including:  * Restaurants, but take away is allowed  * Gyms  * Swimming pools, water parks, spa facilities, hotel pools  * Places of worship, with the exception of funerals  * Libraries  * Amusement parks, bingo halls, gaming halls, playgrounds, bowling alleys and similar places where entertainment and leisure activities take place  * Museums  * Cinemas, theatres, concert venues and similar cultural and entertainment venues.  * Other public places and businesses where cultural, entertainment or leisure activities take place that gather people indoors.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126104250/https://www.thelocal.no/20210123/norway-imposes-tough-lockdown-after-outbreak

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Private gatherings and events  A maximum of five people may gather for private gatherings, such as a birthday in hired premises, outside their own some home. If there are more than five members of one household, then all members of the household are permitted to meet. (New)  There is a limit of ten people for indoor sporting events, cultural events, seminars, faith community gatherings, ceremonies, etc., in addition to a limit of 200 people where everyone in the audience is seated in fixed seating. Up to 50 people are permitted to attend funerals, even if the seating is not fixed. (New)  Regardless, the majority of these events will not comply with the current national guidelines and should therefore be postponed or cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Private gatherings and events  A maximum of five people may gather for private gatherings, such as a birthday in hired premises, outside their own some home. If there are more than five members of one household, then all members of the household are permitted to meet. (New)  There is a limit of ten people for indoor sporting events, cultural events, seminars, faith community gatherings, ceremonies, etc., in addition to a limit of 200 people where everyone in the audience is seated in fixed seating. Up to 50 people are permitted to attend funerals, even if the seating is not fixed. (New)  Regardless, the majority of these events will not comply with the current national guidelines and should therefore be postponed or cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

Most events should be postponed or cancelled.    If an event must be held in spite of this recommendation:  * A maximum of ten individuals may attend private gatherings outside their own home, such as a birthday celebration in rented premises.  * If the private gathering is taking place outdoors, the limit is 20 attendees.  * A maximum of ten people may attend indoor events, while the limit is 200 people for events at which all members of the audience are seated in fixed seating.  * Up to 50 individuals are permitted to attend funerals, even if the seating is not fixed.  * A maximum of 200 people may attend outdoor events, while the limit is 600 people for events at which all members of the audience are seated in fixed seating.  * Events should be postponed if they involve bringing together persons from multiple municipalities.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126101741/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-20-january-2021/id2826828/

Up to 50 people are permitted to attend funerals, even if the seating is not fixed. A maximum of five people - or all members of the same household - may gather for private gatherings outside their own home such as a birthday party  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114092405/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-january-2021/id2826828/

For private gatherings, a maximum of ten individuals may attend private gatherings outside their own home, such as a birthday celebration in rented premises. Coded as 1 to reflect alterations due to covid:     To help maintain enough space, we allow fewer passengers on board our vehicles. Most seats are available, except for the seats behind the driver on buses and trams. There is a limited number of spaces for standing passengers. Please keep recommended distance to others: At least one metre face-to-face.    If the recommended distance cannot be maintained, please disembark and wait for the next departure or use an alternative route.    You have the right to travel as long as you comply with the existing rules for passenger capacity. That means our travel guarantee no longer applies if the means of travel does not have space for you on board.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126113419/https://ruter.no/en/news/travel-advice-for-public-transport/
https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/

In order to maintain control of the spread of infection and to limit new increases in infection rates, strengthened national infection prevention measures are being implemented on a temporary basis for two weeks effective 4 January.  Travel  Avoid all non-essential travel domestically and abroad. Stays in cabins with persons from the same household continue to be permitted provided they take place in accordance with all applicable local and national rules and guidelines.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210106093622/https:/www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/introduction-of-further-national-infection-prevention-measures/id2826466/
It's recommended to stay at home.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114092405/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-january-2021/id2826828/

* Avoid domestic and international travel unless essential.  * Travel to a place of study may be deemed necessary travel.  * Stays in cabins in Norway with members of your household remain permitted, but you must comply with local advice and applicable regulations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126101741/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-20-january-2021/id2826828/
https://web.archive.org/web/20210106161345/https://www.fhi.no/en/op/novel-coronavirus-facts-advice/facts-and-general-advice/entry-quarantine-travel-covid19/

All persons arriving in Norway must quarantine for a period of ten days.  It is possible to end quarantine as of day seven if the person entering Norway tests negative for Covid-19 on two occasions following their arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114092405/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/topics/koronavirus-covid-19/national-measures-from-january-2021/id2826828/

Anyone returning from red countries or areas within the EEA region or Switzerland must stay in quarantine for 10 days after the date of their arrival in Norway.    Violation of the quarantine duty is a criminal offence.    If you have visited an area that triggers quarantine duty during the last 10 days, you are required to take a test for the coronavirus upon arrival to Norway.    Persons who - without due reason - are not willing to undergo testing when arriving in Norway can be fined and will need to implement their quarantine duty at a quarantine hotel.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126113727/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/international-travels/

The Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH/FHI) recommends that anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus is given the opportunity to be tested. Those that should get tested are:    Anyone showing symptoms of COVID-19, including anyone experiencing a sudden onset of symptoms of a respiratory tract infection.  Anyone who is a close contact to someone with confirmed COVID-19*.  Anyone arriving in Norway after having visited a red contry/area during the preceding 10-day period.  Anyone who suspects they might be infected by the coronavirus.  Other persons as assessed by a doctor.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113155943/https://www.helsenorge.no/en/coronavirus/testing-symptoms-and-close-contacts/

Everybody with symptoms can be tested. In Oslo area you can be tested even without being symptomatic  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114102408/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/testing-og-provesvar/

In Oslo area it is required to wear facial coverings in situations where you are not able to keep the distance of one meter - in public transportation, shops etc.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210114103133/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/munnbind/

In Oslo, you must wear a face mask when you cannot keep 1 m away from anyone other than household members in the following situations:  * on public transport and in taxis  * in shops and malls  * at restaurants (open for take away only)  * religious gatherings    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126121147/https://www.oslo.kommune.no/koronavirus/rad-og-regler-i-oslo/munnbind/

Students of grades I-III of primary schools return to school from 18 January. Students of secondary schools, students of continuing education institutions and vocational training centres are taught remotely.    Effective until: 31 January 2021    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations      https://web.archive.org/web/20210120135112/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations  (old Link)

From the 28th of December:  Only essential stores will remain open. However, certain services (such as hairdressers) are allowed to operate under a strict hygiene regime).   Hotels will only be available to uniformed services, medics, patients of specialised hospitals, COS centers and staff hotels.   The ski slopes will close and sports infrastructure is only available to professional athletes.  The following pre-existing restrictions are extended:  Gyms, fitness clubs and aquaparks are closed.   Restaurants are closed, meals are only available for takeaway or delivery.   Hairdressing and beauty salons operate under sanitary conditions.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia  (old Link)

The activity of cultural institutions, including theatres, cinemas, museums, art galleries and cultural centres is suspended.    Effective until: 31 January 2021    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120135112/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations  (old Link)

Effective until: 31 January 2021:    Restrictions concerning gatherings are extended from the 28th of December:  Maximum of 5 people can participate in meetings.   There is a ban on weddings, communions and parties.  In places of worship, a maximum of 1 person/15 metres squared is permitted.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia  (previous Link)

Effective until: 31 January 2021:    Restrictions concerning public transport are extended from the 28th of December:  A maximum of 50% seating occupancy or 30% of all seating and standing positions with 50% of seating vacant in public transport vehicles.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia  (previous Link)

No change in policy. It is recommended not to leave the house other than for essential trips.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120135849/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/questions-and-answers  (Link from earlier entry)
