Any person entering the country via organised transport is subject to a 10 day quarantine.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210101210448/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przedluzamy-etap-odpowiedzialnosci-i-wprowadzamy-dodatkowe-ograniczenia
Travel bans on entry from certain counties remain in place      https://web.archive.org/web/20210117145504/https://travelbans.org/europe/poland/

"On 13 June 2020, Poland resumed border traffic within the framework of internal borders of the EU. It means that traveling and crossing the internal borders of the EU is permitted. Travelers have regained their right to freely enter, leave or transit through the territory of the Republic of Poland. Quarantine is not required. One should consider the restrictions which are in force in a neighbouring country while planning a trip abroad."    "Important!   From 28 December 2020 to 31 January 2021, compulsory quarantine will be imposed on persons who have crossed Poland’s border (both an external and an internal EU border) by plane, bus, or other means of collective transport - for 10 days, counting from the day following the day on which the border was crossed."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210120135849/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/questions-and-answers

According to a post by the Polish government, they are "convinced that support from the Financial Shield 2.0 will compensate companies for the vast majority of losses due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the period November - March," suggesting that the aid will at least last until March 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210117191351/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/35-mld-zl-wsparcia-dla-firm--rusza-tarcza-finansowa-pfr-20  http://web.archive.org/web/20210127095522/https://assets.kpmg/content/dam/kpmg/us/pdf/2020/03/covid-19-tax-developments-summary.pdf

The Ministry of Finance again postponed the effective date for a withholding tax collection mechanism applicable for both corporate income tax and individual (personal) income tax purposes. The new effective date is 30 June 2021. An explanatory memorandum accompanying the decrees announcing the suspension explains the postponement is in response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210117194109/https://home.kpmg/us/en/home/insights/2021/01/tnf-poland-withholding-tax-collection-system-postponed-30-june-2021.html    See also, extensive overview of all measures implemented:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210127095522/https://assets.kpmg/content/dam/kpmg/us/pdf/2020/03/covid-19-tax-developments-summary.pdf
General campaign running on the official website of the government:    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127100558/https://www.gov.pl/

General levels of contact tracing seem low, as:    "Just 1.9% of the Polish population have downloaded the government’s COVID-19 contact tracing app since its launch in June. That is one of the lowest levels of take-up among European countries. Such low adoption means that the app will not be effective, according to experts. The system, which cost around 2.5 million zloty (€0.6 million) to develop, has also been hit by concerns over privacy and functionality."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143636/https://notesfrompoland.com/2020/09/11/uptake-of-covid-contact-tracing-app-under-2-in-poland-among-the-lowest-rates-in-europe/    "Contact tracing using epidemiological interviews is carried out for people who may have had contact with an infected person according to the epidemiological criteria of COVID-19 case explained above. Data are gathered by the local sanitary inspection units. The Minister of Health publishes aggregated information about new cases, deaths and recoveries via its Twitter account. Data is not disaggregated into age groups or by geographic location."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143626/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/poland/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.4+Monitoring+and+surveillance&Type=Section

Covering the mouth and nose in public spaces is obligatory throughout the entire country!    It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:    -on streets, roads and in town squares, within cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, vehicle parking areas, forest car parks,  -in buses, trams and trains,  -in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  -in cinemas and theatres,  -at physician’s offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  -in churches, at schools and universities,  -In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.    Where is it not mandatory to cover your mouth and nose? In forests, parks, green squares, botanical gardens, historic gardens, family community gardens and on beaches as well as while travelling by private car.    Important!  Exemption from the obligation to cover the mouth and nose is limited only to persons who have a medical certificate or a document confirming:    -a pervasive developmental disorder,  -a mental disorder,  -moderate, severe or profound intellectual disability,  -difficulties in uncovering the mouth or nose on their own.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations

The Polish Vaccine roll out begins on the 30th of December. Medics, social workers, uniformed services, teachers and senior citizens are the first groups to get the jab (groups A and C). The current vaccination on offer is the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101162924/https://www.thefirstnews.com/article/poland-receives-first-covid-19-vaccines---pm-18660

In São Miguel, in the Azores, distance learning is now required for all students, irrespectively of their level.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118152233/https://www.publico.pt/2021/01/07/sociedade/noticia/acores-apertam-cerco-covid19-escolas-fechadas-recolher-obrigatorio-restaurantes-encerrados-15h-1945400

The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th (in mainland Portugal).  All educational establishments will remain open and continue to operate as they have been until now.  According to a document distributed during the briefing of the Head of Government, the measure applies to nurseries, schools and universities.  Note: In certain municipalities in the Azores schools remain fully closed (all levels) - reason why the code has remain unchanged despite these measures.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210118163525/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-01-13/schools-to-remain-open-in-full-operation/57684

Mainland Portugal : "The Prime Minister announced a 15-day school break , which takes effect on Friday (January 22), which is justified by a "precautionary principle" because of the increase in the number of cases of the most contagious variant of SARS-CoV-2 , which have grown from around 8% prevalence in the past week to around 20% today."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172354/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-01-21-Covid-19.-Governo-decide-fechar-todos-os-niveis-de-ensino-por-15-dias  Madeira Island : "Face-to-face classes for students in the 3rd Cycle and Secondary Education are suspended in all schools in the Autonomous Region of Madeira  until February 21 .  - All other levels of education : daycare centers / kindergartens / pre-school / 1st and 2nd cycles / special and professional education maintain their activities in person . - All out-of-school activities, in person, are suspended until February 21st."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19  Note: Since in Madeira, schools are only closed for some levels the code remains unchanged.
See latest Measures still in Place.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th in mainland Portugal.  "Establishments and services open to the public: essential goods stores, grocery stores,, supermarkets and hypermarkets may operate without time restrictions; health services, offices, dentists and pharmacies; restaurants and cafes may only operate on a take-away or home delivery basis; fairs and markets are only allowed to sell food products.  Establishments and services closed to the public: hairdressers / barber shops; gyms closed; museums, cultural and leisure spaces; prohibited events."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. (...) Shops and others commercial premises, with the exception of pharmacies, health centres and petrol stations, will close at 6pm on weekdays and at 5pm on weekends and public holidays. Restaurants can remain open until 10pm for takeaway and food delivery services only."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  Note: Since in Madeira, non-essential services are allowed to be open and restrictions apply to the opening schedules - meaning these are not fully closed - the T(argeted) flag was kept.

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 30 January, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on 15 January (...) Establishments and services closed to the public: hairdressers / barber shops; gyms; sports facilities, even outdoors; museums, cultural and leisure spaces;    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2317.150    Azores : "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From midnight on Saturday, January 30:    Low Risk islands: "Closure of all drinks and similar establishments, with dance spaces"  Medium Risk Islands : "Closure of all restaurants, drinks and similar establishments at *8:00 pm*, with or without a show and with or without terrace service, including spaces for holding events, except for take-away or home delivery purposes (...) Prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages after 8:00 pm, unless in restaurant service"  High risk Islands : "Closure of daycare centers and ATL; (...) Closure of gymnasiums and covered swimming pools, with the practice of sports in these spaces being prohibited; Closure of casinos and gambling establishments"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891    Madeira : "Until February 21, all activities of an industrial, commercial and service nature must, imperatively, close:    - During the days of the week : until 18h.  - Saturdays, Sundays and municipal holidays : until 17h.    Until February 21, all gambling establishments, casinos, bingo or similar, must close:  - Weekends : until 17h.  - During the week : at 6 pm.    Until the 21st of February restaurants are allowed to open:    - During the days of the week (Monday to Friday): until 6pm.  - Weekends : until 17h, and the takeaway service and home deliveries will be closed from that time."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Note: Since in Madeira AND in low risk islands in the Azores establishments are allowed to be open (despite the restrictions in terms of schedules) the flag (targeted remains unchanged).

As per latest Nation measures in effect on 8th January 12, 2021  Events and celebrations limited to 5 people, unless from the same household.  Weddings and baptisms limited to 50 people  http://web.archive.org/web/20210110062642/https://covid19estamoson.gov.pt/medidas-covid19-ambito-nacional-v2/

Mainland Portugal: "The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th. There will be a general duty of home retreat. The movement and concentration of groups of more than 5 people is prohibited, in private or public spaces, unless they belong to the same household. (...) Public events are prohibited".  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  Madeira: "Due to the epidemiological evolution in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, and according to Government Resolution No. 19/2021, the Regional Government of Madeira has adopted a set of new preventive measures, applicable with immediate effect as from the 13th of January, and which will remain in force until the 31st of this month. Gatherings of more than 5 persons are prohibited, unless from the same family unit, on the public way, or in any other public area (...)"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111082652/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/en-gb/useful-info/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/information-to-visitors-%28covid-19%29  Azores: On the Regional Government website, that includes the list of social and cultural events, the large majority of events for the month of January were either cancelled or will take place online, due to the COVID-19 restrictions currently in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210119141108/https://agendacores.pt/

Mainland Portugal : "There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel (...) Prohibited events "    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2317.150    Madeira: "limitation to 5 people in the access, circulation or permanence in the public road and in other spaces of commercial and restaurant nature, except if they belong to the same household;  limitation to 5 people per group, unless belonging to the same household, in areas of restoration of shopping centers and restaurants, cafes and pastry shops 300m from schools; celebrations and other events that involve an agglomeration of people in excess of 5 people are prohibited, unless they belong to the same household, including cultural shows or events of any nature, with the exception of religious ceremonies, provided that limitation of capacity contained in paragraph 10 of Resolution no. 839/2020, of 5 November." From midnight on Saturday, January 30:    Low Risk islands: "Limitation of gatherings on the public road of a maximum number of eight people, unless they are from the same household"  Medium Risk Islands : "Limitation of gatherings on the public road of a maximum number of six people, unless they are from the same household"  High risk Islands : "Limitation of gatherings on the public road of a maximum number of four people, unless they are from the same household"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891

State of Emergency in force until 15 January.   -	The use of face masks is mandatory.  -	Public transports are limited to 2/3 of the capacity.  -	In taxis / TVDE, the front seats must be used only by the driver, and passenger occupancy cannot exceed 2/3 of the remaining space.  -	Rent-a-Car - In vehicles with a capacity of 5 seats or less, they can be fully occupied if they belong to the same household. If the vehicle has a capacity for more than 5 seats, its capacity is limited to 2/3 of the total, unless they are part of the same household.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th.  There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to travel, except for authorized travel namely for acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities; health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people", among others.  "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, a curfew is in place: on weekdays from 7pm to 5am and  on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am"  "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. The island of São Miguel is classified as high risk. On this island, until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home as follows: on weekdays from 8pm to 5am and n weekends from 3pm to 5am."  Note: Since the measures in the Azores DO NOT apply to all 9 islands (currently only 1 has a curfew a T(argeted) flag has been selected.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Mainland Portugal : "There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out: acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities (if accompanied by a statement); health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people; school attendance; short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household; pet walk; travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation; homecoming within the framework of permitted situations; refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys."    Madeira : "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home: on weekdays from 7pm to 5am and on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am"    Azores: "The autonomous region of the Azores is currently in a state of emergency. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus. There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. Each level has its own restrictions. The island of São Miguel is currently classified as high risk. The remaining islands (8) are classified as low risk. In São Miguel, until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home as follows: on weekdays from 8pm to 5am and on weekends from 3pm to 5am.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2339.62    Note: Since the measures in the Azores DO NOT apply to all 9 islands (currently only 1 has a curfew a T(argeted) flag has been selected.

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 30 January, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on 15 January. (...) There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out: acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities (if accompanied by a statement); health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people; short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household; pet walk; travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation; homecoming within the framework of permitted situations; refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys."    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2285.0-2285.111    Madeira: "Until February 21, circulation on public roads is prohibited:     - During the days of the week : between 19h and 05h the next day.  - Saturdays, Sundays and local holidays : between 18h and 05h the next day"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19      Azores:  "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From Saturday, January 30:    Low and medium risk islands : NO stay at home requirements.  High risk islands: "Prohibition of pedestrian, car, motorized or similar circulation on public roads between 8:00 pm and 5:00 am the following day on weekdays and between 3:00 pm and 5:00 am the day after weekend, except as provided in paragraph 4"    NOTE: In low and middle risk islands in the Azores there are no stay at home requirements which is why the code remains unchanged despite the additional measures announced by the regional government.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891

Individuals should only travel between the islands (Madeira and the Azores) for essential purposes. If one has to travel from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago (Azores), a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before travelling and completing a passenger questionnaire before depart are required.     In mainland Portugal, there are no specific restrictions on mobility to cross land borders but the Government recommends only leaving home only for essential travel (T flag applied since the travel restrictions do not apply).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

Inter-island travel  "You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  Movement between municipalities in mainland Portugal during the weekend will be prohibited, between 8pm on Friday, January 29 to 5am on Monday, February 1.  Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ  Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.  -Travel from other countries are prohibited.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210112033409/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to: - European Union countries; - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom; - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay. It is not necessary to present the COVID-19 Test on these flights, unless the destinations are the archipelagos of Madeira or the Azores. - Only passengers on flights from the UK who are nationals or legally resident in Portugal are allowed to enter national territory.  United Kingdom (UK): - All passengers must present a negative test to COVID 19. - Upon arrival in the national territory, citizens who do not have proof of negative test results will be sent by the competent authorities to be carried out inside the airport. In this case, citizens will have to remain in isolation, under the terms defined by health authorities. - On flights from the UK to Madeira, passengers who are not tested negative should do so on arrival and between 5 and 7 days and should await the results in prophylactic isolation."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

In addition to restrictions previously in place, "The government has decided to suspend flights to and from Brazil from 00:00 on Friday due to the evolution of the pandemic, the increase in cases of infection by the new coronavirus and the detection of new strains.  "Until February 14, all flights, commercial or private, of all airlines to and from Brazil are suspended. The rules now laid down also apply to flights to and from the UK," the Home Office (MAI) said in a statement."  Source: https://archive.vn/0HexI

"The Government approved a diploma that follows the rule of the State budget that provides that the mechanisms for reducing or suspending workers' contracts - the so-called lay-off, which currently has three versions - no longer imply wage cuts, passing the maturity to be guaranteed to 100%.      However, according to the communiqué of the Council of Ministers, in the case of the classic lay-off of the Labor Code, which has existed for several decades, wage cuts of one third of the salary continue to apply if the lay-off has started before 1 January 2021.     "It is established that all workers who are covered by the simplified lay-off, lay-off of the Labor Code (motivated by the Covid-19 disease pandemic and which begins after January 1, 2021) and extraordinary support for the progressive resumption of activity will receive 100% of their normal gross remuneration up to 3 Minimum Guaranteed Monthly Remuneration (RMMG) ", that is, 1,995 euros," with no additional effort by employers ", indicates the Government in the statement of the Council of Ministers .    Thus, a lay-off that started in October, for example, and continues until March 2021, will not be covered by the 100% payment guarantee."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130171645/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/detalhe/governo-aprova-lay-off-com-salarios-pagos-a-100-mas-abre-excecoes    Note: Since the measure only applies to those who make the request AFTER January 1, and not to all workers in lay-off, which is whythe code remains unchanged.

"On mainland Portugal and in the autonomous regions of Madeira and the Azores, you must wear a face mask in all enclosed spaces. You should wear your face covering when you enter the building and keep it on until you leave.    On mainland Portugal and in the Azores, you must also wear a face mask outdoors where it is not possible to maintain a 2m social distance from people outside your family group. In Madeira and Porto Santo, the use of a face mask outdoors is mandatory, except when driving, exercising, while on the beach or walking the recommended routes in forest and mountain areas.    These measures apply to everyone over the age of 10 on mainland Portugal and in the Azores, and over the age of 5 in Madeira and Porto Santo."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

A,C:      Portugal begins vaccinating frontline health workers on 27 December. News reports and government immunisation dashboard shows that frontline workers and elderly are the two eligible groups currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111135939/https://www.publico.pt/2020/12/23/sociedade/noticia/portugal-recebe-70200-doses-vacina-covid-28-dezembro-1944109    https://archive.vn/m1Bk9

A, C:    Vaccination task force coordinator Francisco Ramos has set out Portugal’s ‘programme’. If all goes according to plan (meaning the Pfizer vaccination gets European Medicine Agency approval later this month), Phase One will start in January immunising:    People over the age of 50 with at least one of the following pathologies: cardiac insufficiency, heart disease, renal insufficiency or chronic respiratory disease requiring ventilation.  Residents of old people’s homes and those interned in professional continuous care facilities  Healthcare professionals directly involved in caring for the sick, Armed Forces personnel, security forces and all ‘essential service personnel’ (criteria still to be defined).    Code remains the same as this extra clause for clinically vulnerable has not yet been bought into effect    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111141448/https://www.portugalresident.com/portugals-vaccination-programme-opens-with-950000-getting-shots-between-january-and-february/

Priština said on Wednesday it secured two million anti-coronavirus vaccines, with the first shipment of Pfizer’s injections expected in February and planned to vaccinate 20,000 people daily, according to Prime Minister Avdulah Hoti, and Health Minister Armend Zemaj.  Hoti added that besides 535,000 Pfizer-BioNtech vaccines, some 600,000 doses would come from Austria and an additional 720,000 based on the World Health Organization COVAX programme.    The vaccination for 1.8 million people in Kosovo will be free of charge and voluntarily.  According to Hoti, the first to be vaccinated will be health system employees and people over 65.  Notes: A & C    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130101810/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/kosovo-to-get-two-million-anti-coronavirus-vaccines-first-shipment-in-february/

A decision on reopening the schools in Romania will be taken on February 2, after a review of the country's coronavirus situation, prime minister Florin Citu said on Tuesday, January 19. According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.20) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities.  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/un88p

On 20th of November, The National Committee for Emergency Situations published Decision no.55 regarding the approval of the list of countries/areas of epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on persons arriving in Romania from them. Also, there are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions).  According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020 of The National Committee for Emergency Situations, the list of countries of high epidemiological risk for which the quarantine measure is instituted on the persons arriving in Romania from them was approved. The National Institute of Public Health published the lists of states with high epidemiological risk.  Link: https://archive.fo/pUara, https://archive.fo/s1GX6 and https://archive.fo/wip/QkpvU.

The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. It was released the National Information Platform on vaccination against COVID-19.  Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/O0MTX#selection-697.0-697.76

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

A:    The Government approved the Vaccination Strategy against SARA-CoV-2 in Romania. The document establishes the vision, principles, and mode of action for the administration in Romania of COVID-19 vaccines authorized by the European Medicines Agency. There are three stages of vaccination: first for health care workers, second -for the population at risk, for essential staff and the last stage – for the general population. On 27th of December, the first stage started with the first 10 000 doses of vaccines in all 10 infectious disease hospitals on the front lines in the fight against COVID-19.  Link: https://archive.fo/KYZQL, https://archive.fo/wip/C61Wh and https://archive.fo/wip/pnsuB

Second stage of the vaccination campaign started on 15th of January and is aimed at people over 65 age, people with chronic diseases (regardless of age) and key staff working in key areas. The coordinator of the National Committee for the Planning of COVID-19 Vaccination in Romania, announced how the appointments of people over 65 years of age and those with chronic diseases can be made. (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are used).  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/IzHsa and https://archive.fo/wip/qeZ7F

C:    Vaccination against COVID-19 has started in Moscow. The City Government is regularly extending the groups of residents who can sign up for vaccination. Currently, these groups include:    Muscovites over 60 (they are at the highest risk of severe COVID-19 and complications);  People with chronic conditions who are required to stay at home during the pandemic;  College and university students aged 18 and older.    Also, people aged 18 and over who work in the following fields and organisations can get vaccinated. In the future, it will be available to all Moscow residents.    As this is not yet available across all of Russia, I have coded this as a 1 for group C elderly groups, until more evidence emerges that this is accessible country wide    http://web.archive.org/web/20210108222859/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/

Classes in primary and secondary schools will be continued from 18 January according to the dynamics that took place in September. High school students will attend classes every other week (half a class in a shift), and elementary school students will go to school every other day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111202631/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166116/government-adopts-recommendation-of-crisis-response-team-to-keep-current-measures.php
No changes recorded.

The Education Ministry said earlier that elementary and high schools would reopen using the same model for classes that was in place since September 1 which means that elementary school children in grades 1 to 4 will go to school every day in smaller groups while grades 5 to 8 will go to school every other day and online. High school students will either go to school one week and have online classes every other week or stay at home for online schooling to the end of the year. Classes will be 30 minutes long instead of the customary 45 and the school year will be five days longerr because of the coronavirus pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234843/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/serbian-schools-start-second-semester-teachers-unhappy/

A:     On 30 December 2020, Minister of Health Zlatibor Loncar stated in Novi Sad that the vaccination of health workers began today and that those working in infectious diseases clinics and emergency centres have already been vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102195559/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165717/vaccination-of-health-workers-begins.php

A, C:    State Secretary of the Ministry of Health Mirsad Djerlek announced: "We plan to vaccinate about 11,000 people by the end of the week, with half of the vaccines being allocated to health workers and half to gerontology centers and social welfare institutions".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111210924/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/165825/vaccination-of-11000-people-planned-until-end-of-week.php

A, C:      The Prime Minister Ana Brnabic stated that that there will be enough vaccines available for all citizens who want to be vaccinated against coronavirus (agreements exist for 8 million doses for 4 million of inhabitants). The plan for mass immunisation will be adopted by the crisis response team during the week of 18-24 January 2021.  Brnabic expressed the expectation that the first vaccination point will be opened at the Belgrade Fair by the end of the week of 18-24 January, adding that from 11 January, citizens will be able to apply to the system through which they will be able to express their desire to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111212830/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166035/preconditions-for-beginning-of-mass-vaccination-provided.php    Two groups coded as insufficient evidence to warrant higher code

A, C:    No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.ph  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111204053/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/

A, C. No change recorded in groups.    Pfizer, Sputnik V vaccine.    "On January 16, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic said that the country expected to receive an additional 250,000 doses of Sputnik V vaccine on Tuesday. According to Vucic, Serbia would vaccinate 80 percent of its seven million population with vaccines developed by different pharmaceutical companies.  "As of today, 28 percent are in favor of receiving Pfizer vaccine, 40 percent have chosen Sputnik V, the others do not care which one [to choose]," Derlek said during a television appearance."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210119002717/https://sputniknews.com/world/202101181081797801-live-updates-global-coronavirus-death-toll-reaches-2-million-people/

Pfizer, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm are currently in use. Negotiations are in progress for the AstraZeneca vaccine.    On 19 January, mass vaccinations began at the Belgrade Fair, Brnabic reiterated that mass vaccination of Serbian citizens is starting today and to that purpose, the first big vaccination site is opened at the Belgrade Fair and at the Torlak Institute. She specified that the first ones to be vaccinated are members of the Ministry of the Interior, the Serbian Army and other security services.    The Secretary of State appealed to the citizens to apply for vaccination in as many numbers as possible, but also to adhere to the protection and distance measures.    Because Serbia is also working on acquiring more vaccine, did not yet code as 5 as the policy as there isn't evidence yet that access is Universal with the limited supply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220302/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166671/very-good-start-of-immunisation-in-serbia.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220013/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166467/mass-vaccination-at-18-points-starts-in-belgrade.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166398/mass-vaccination-in-serbia-starts-today.php

Pupils and student cannot come back to school after the school holidays and are obliged to distance learning on a national level. 1 January 2021     From January the 1st, under the partial lockdown restrictions, family units are not allowed to mix with others from outside of the household.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210118155140/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     Due to the rising number of COVID-19 cases people were no longer allowed to form bubbles after 1 January 2021. While the decree that sets out the rules for movement and gatherings since 1 January does not explicitly ban gatherings. The rules governing the movement of people are strict and make it nearly impossible for people to gather without breaking any of the movement restrictions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125115028/https://www.slov-lex.sk/pravne-predpisy/SK/ZZ/2020/453/20201231      At the same time, the limit for people attending christenings, funerals and weddings remains at 6, see:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210114175952/http://www.minv.sk/swift_data/source/verejna_sprava/vestnik_vlady_sr_rok_2021/ciastka_2_2021.pdf

Negative result will mean an exception from the lockdown restrictions.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118155140/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118190824/https://korona.gov.sk/

The government is implementing a period of free nationwide testing between January 18th to January 26th. Those who test negative are validated for activity between January 27th and Feb 2nd. (From Feb 2nd, a second round of testing begins).   A negative test, complete vaccination (two doses, the second one taken at least 14 days prior to Jan. 27), or proof of recovery from COVID-19 within the last 90 days will be required for nearly all activities outside the home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124175919/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

A:    No policy changes, workers in health care / social services are eligible to sign-up for vaccination currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109223845/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=frontpage&Itemid=1  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109224013/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220424/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Update immunization policy is in place from 18 January – currently health care professionals and other workers in health care facilities are eligible + newly also old people in nursing homes. People from critical infrastructure will be moved to the list of replacements, meaning they will receive the vaccination only if there is unused vaccine or someone fails to attend.    In the second phase:  residents of senior's homes and people over 65, patients with serious diagnoses, such as diabetes, oncological diseases, auto-immune diseases, cardiovascular issues and other chronic diseases     In the third phase: people in communities with a high risk of fast coronavirus spread like teachers, people living in marginalised Roma communities, homeless people and asylum seekers    In the fourth phase: members of the general public older than 18     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118213749/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22574807/vaccination-strategy-to-change.html

"On the basis of the opinion of the expert group for the containment and control of the COVID-19 epidemic, the Government decided to extend the closure of schools and kindergartens for seven days until 18 January 2021."  Source: https://archive.fo/fqtMv

No policy change. In Slovenia, distance learning is carried out in all primary, music and secondary schools and in faculties. Kindergartens have been working in a limited capacity.  https://archive.vn/508cI

From 23rd January, in  in nine out of 12 regions of Slovenia, kindergartens and the first three years of primary school are permitted to reopen.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125041347/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/432806/slovenia-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-eased-in-nine-regions-from-jan-23-update-24

The Government issued the Ordinance on temporary suspension of the sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia, which enters into force on 9 January 2021 and will apply until 15 January 2021.    To restrict the movement of people and contain and manage the COVID-19 epidemic, a new Ordinance on the temporary suspension of the sale of goods and services to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia is proposed, which temporarily prohibits the offering and sale of goods and services directly to consumers in the Republic of Slovenia with certain exceptions that are necessary to meet citizens’ basic needs or are important for ensuring safety and health.    Some businesses are closed while some remain open, including hairdressing services.    https://archive.vn/vWP8z

From 23rd January, in  in nine out of 12 regions of Slovenia,  limited nonessential businesses and services can reopen including markets, museums, libraries, hairdressers, and mechanics.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125041347/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/432806/slovenia-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-eased-in-nine-regions-from-jan-23-update-24
No policy change. Gathering is permitted only to groups of persons who are close family members or share the same household.  https://archive.vn/508cI

Public passenger transport is carried out in a limited capacity. Considering that faculties, secondary and primary schools, and kindergartens are still closed, public passenger transport is carried out according to the school holiday timetable.    The recommendations of the National Institute of Public Health on mask wearing, hand disinfection, vehicle occupancy, and entering and exiting vehicles must be followed.     https://archive.vn/508cI
No policy change. Movement between municipalities is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  https://archive.vn/508cI

At midnight on Saturday, 9 January, an amendment to the ordinance on state border crossing will enter into force, which will introduce the option to prove that a person does not have COVID-19 with both rapid antigen tests and PCR tests. When entering the Republic of Slovenia, negative PCR tests are required in case of arrival from third countries, which must not be older than 48 hours. Rapid antigen tests are valid only if done in the EU or the Schengen Area.     Testing with rapid antigen tests at border crossings has been abolished on the external Schengen border. The five border crossings and the Jože Pucnik Airport that have been offering rapid tests will therefore no longer continue to do so.    Anyone who does not present this proof will have to go into quarantine, which can, however, be lifted if the person takes a test within five days of the decision being issued.     Finland is removed from the red list, which means that entry from this country is possible without quarantine or a negative test. There are no changes in the list of third countries.    https://archive.vn/vWP8z  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110170450/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-01-07-the-governments-priorities-are-citizens-health-and-safety-the-pupils-of-the-first-three-grades-of-primary-school-and-the-full-opening-of-kindergartens/

No policy change. Masks are mandatory:  - in all closed public spaces,  - on public transport,  - in open public spaces or outside if physical distancing of at least two metres cannot be maintained and  - in personal vehicles.  https://archive.vn/508cI

A, C:  The vaccination campaign continues, with the priority given to those over 85 and the remainder going to health workers.  The Pfizer vaccine is being used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118212237/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-01-13-rise-in-hospital-admissions/

"The temporary regulations give principals a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs. There are opportunities for the principal to take action if the school is open or if the school is or has been closed.  The Swedish Public Health Agency has previously recommended that upper secondary schools partially close and switch to distance education from Monday 7 December 2020 until Wednesday 6 January 2021. The Swedish Public Health Agency has now decided that this recommendation will be extended and apply until 24 January 2021."  Note: Since principals have the authority to decide whether to close high-schools, depending on the regional situation, and this is only a recommendation - making it unlikely for upper-secondary schools to close countrywide - a Targeted flag has been selected.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221201801/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

In addition to the measures mentioned in the previous note, on 10 January, a new covid-19 law came into force which enabled the government to restrict numbers in shops and businesses, and close public places such as shopping centres and gyms. It has not yet mandated such closures, but from 10 January, shops, shopping centers, gyms and bathhouses must calculate the number of visitors to allow for 10 sqm per visitor. In addition, the maximum limit of 8 participants will also apply to private events in party centres and club houses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112112903/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/butiker-gym-och-kopcentrum-maste-begransa-antalet-besokare/

Temporary shutdown of public buildings  All activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Public gatherings and events may have a maximum of 8 participants meaning that no public events are allowed. The only exception in place is for funerals, where a maximum of 20 participants is allowed.   "Public gatherings include: gatherings that constitute demonstrations or which are otherwise held for discussion, expression of opinion or providing information on public or private matters; lectures and speeches held for the purposes of teaching or for public or civic education; gatherings for religious practice; theatrical and cinema performances, concerts and other gatherings for the performance of artistic work, and other gatherings at which freedom of assembly is exercised.  Public events include: competitions and exhibitions in sports and aviation; dance performances; fairground amusements and parades; markets and fairs circus performances. other events not regarded as public gatherings. Schools, public transport, private events and visits to shops are excluded."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend. The general temporary entry ban for non-EU non-essential travellers as well as travellers from the UK and Denmark remains in place.     As of 1 January 2021, people exempt from the ban and travelling from the UK are required to present a negative test result at the most 72 hours before arriving in Sweden.     This requirement does not apply to those transporting goods – who may therefore enter the country without presenting a negative test result. This is to avoid impeding the transport of essential goods, such as pharmaceuticals or medical equipment.    Nor does the requirement apply to Swedish citizens, who always have the right to enter Sweden. However, the recommendation of the Public Health Agency of Sweden still applies, i.e. that everyone who has been in the UK should get tested for COVID-19 immediately upon arrival to Sweden, remain at home and get tested again after five days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104160031/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/12/negative-covid-19-test-result-required-for-entry-into-sweden-from-uk/

"The Swedish government has announced that entry bans to Sweden from the UK and Denmark will be introduced, due to the new variant of the SARS-Cov-2 virus. The ban will take effect at midnight, the night before Tuesday 22 December. (...)   The ban mainly means that all persons except Swedish citizens traveling from the United Kingdom or Denmark will be expelled if they try to travel into Sweden. Exceptions will be possible for people who transport goods and the like. For Denmark, people who work or live in Sweden will also be exempt. People from both the United Kingdom and Denmark who are judged to have urgent family reasons will also be able to be exempted from the entry ban.  The entry ban applies until 21 January 2021 or until further notice."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108134639/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/visiting-sweden-during-the-covid-19-pandemic

Temporary entry ban to Sweden  The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125010813/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Short-term lay-offs may currently be granted for a maximum of nine consecutive months. The Government will propose that this time limit be temporarily removed until 30 June 2021. In practice, this means that short-term lay-offs granted in 2020 can be extended by up to a further seven months, or until 30 June 2021 at the latest.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125013744/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/11/additional-crisis-measures-for-businesses/

Measures include (i) additional expenditures on wage subsidies for short-term leave, increase in transfers to relevant agencies to deal with the coronavirus outbreak and its repercussions, temporary payment of sick leave (also for sole traders), loans to SMEs, more funding to the media, cultural and sports sectors and for education and training, temporary rent subsidies to vulnerable sectors, temporarily more generous unemployment benefits, expanded active labor market policies, expansion of education, initiatives for green jobs and summer jobs for young people, temporary reduction of employers’ social security contributions, increased testing for COVID-19, additional general grants to municipalities and regions, temporary grants to businesses based on their loss of turnover to cover their fixed costs, more funding to train health workers, supplementary housing allowances to families with children.    On December 10, the Government proposed to extend the state credit guarantee program for loans to companies until June 30, 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125014308/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
Ongoing public campaign.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108134426/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/fragor-och-svar/

The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that adults with symptoms of COVID-19 get tested to see if they have an ongoing infection. The same recommendation applies to children of school age and older, i.e., from about 6 years of age. Younger children of preschool age are primarily advised to stay at home if they are ill, without taking a test. It is the regions that decide which people to test, and there may be regional variations from the national recommendations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125020028/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/
No change: https://web.archive.org/web/20210108135343/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

In the next step, contact those who may have been exposed to infection. This is done either by the infected himself, in dialogue with a vector, or by a vector in the responsible region. Anyone contacted in a contagion is informed of what this means and what action may need to be taken. Each person receiving a positive test result (PCR test) gives rise to a new infection tracking.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125020700/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/testning-och-smittsparning/smittsparning/

The government continues to limit the services of public transport. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening." Passengers are subject to temperature checks."    "Rail services are suspended."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

There has been no significant change since the last date input. The government continues to not require people to stay at home. There are rumours that a lockdown might have been introduced since 1 November 2020, but the source is unofficial and cannot be confirmed. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201116183946/https://for.kg/news-674059-en.html    https://www.barrons.com/news/turkmen-leader-opens-new-hospital-insists-country-virus-free-01605340808

The government continues to restrict internal movement. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening."    "Domestic flights remain operational, but with a reduced service. Passengers are subject to temperature checks."    "[N]ewspapers report that a COVID-19 test result is required for boarding domestic flights."    "Rail services are suspended."    "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. There are some reports of restrictions on interstate travel."    "Domestic flights are operating on a significantly reduced schedule. Security forces have erected checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1611.0-1611.348    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

The government continues to close its border. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and land borders are closed to passenger traffic. Some press reporting indicates that international flight restrictions are expected to continue through January 1, 2020."    "Commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan are suspended. Occasional, tightly controlled, charter flights are the only means of entering or leaving the country by air."    "As part of ongoing efforts to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), authorities in Turkmenistan have extended their suspensions of international flights until at least Jan. 31. Domestic rail and bus services also remain suspended until at least Jan. 31. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan remain closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility. While freight traffic is generally allowed to transit the border, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 test certificate, signed within the previous 24 hours."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1611.0-1611.348    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus
The government continues to not offer any income support. No relevant information can be found in articles reviewing the country’s economic policy.    https://archive.vn/pdIkh
The government continues to not offer any debt/contract relief. No relevant information can be found in articles reviewing the country’s economic policy.    https://archive.vn/pdIkh

The government continues to deny the existence of any COVID case in the country, but there are coordinated public information campaigns in place.     "The Government of Turkmenistan’s Ministry of Health has established a COVID-19 hotline (tel. +993 12 73 9535) where citizens may receive information about the virus, including prevention and treatment, in both Russian and Turkmen languages."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5

The government continues to not implement any testing policy since it continues to deny the presence of COVID in the country.     However, according to the US Embassy in Turkmenistan, "COVID-19 testing is offered in Ashgabat at Jemgyyetcilik Saglygy we Iymit Merkezi (the Virology Laboratory of the Public Health and Nutrition Center) on Gorgoly 84, Ashgabat. The test costs 100 manat for citizens of Turkmenistan and $43 for foreign citizens." Whether citizens of Turkmenistan can actually access the COVID test is unclear.    https://archive.fo/cxSs5

The government continues to not implement any contact tracing measures. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still denies the presence of COVID in the country.    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1607.0-1607.900

The government continues to require people to wear masks in public spaces. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Masks are required in most public places, including public transit."    "It is compulsory to wear a facemask when in public."    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208052008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201208051714/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

Please note the entry of "Government funded" is an estimation, which might need to be adjusted later on based on new information.    https://archive.vn/Evnt8    https://archive.vn/wT1kV

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 ours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and also will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/symcM

Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days.   Link: https://archive.fo/2qeZb

Link: https://archive.fo/wip/qA4lj

No change to policies regarding school closures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110172936/https://moz.gov.ua/article/reform-plan/maksim-stepanov-moz-napoljagae-na-vvedenni-zaplanovanogo-posilenogo-karantinu-z-8-do-24-sichnja

Ukraine government implements extended quarantine measures as announced on 9th December 2020. The enhanced measures will be in place from 00:00 on the 8th January 2021 until 00:00 on the 25th January 2021. These measures refer to the closing of all schools across Ukraine, the closing of most workplaces, and banning all public events.    For the period of enhanced quarantine measures it is prohibited to visit educational institutions of any form of ownership, except kindergartens.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210116223522/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-vidsogodni-v-ukraini-vstupili-v-diju-posileni-karantinni-obmezhennja  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110165940/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/operativna-informacija-pro-poshirennja-koronavirusnoi-infekcii-2019-cov19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110170949/https://moz.gov.ua/article/reform-plan/maksim-stepanov-vidsogodni-v-ukraini-vstupili-v-diju-posileni-karantinni-obmezhennja  https://web.archive.org/web/20210116221348/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:  -	Visiting educational institutions by groups of more than 20 people, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized art education institutions.  -	Visiting educational institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution are in self-isolation.    /web/20210125185434/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

No change to policies regarding workplaces closing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110172936/https://moz.gov.ua/article/reform-plan/maksim-stepanov-moz-napoljagae-na-vvedenni-zaplanovanogo-posilenogo-karantinu-z-8-do-24-sichnja

From 08 January until 24 January, "enhanced" adaptive quarantine measures are in place.  On 13 January, the "regular" adaptive quarantine measures were extended until 28 February.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210116231338/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-posileni-karantinni-obmezhennja-v-ukraini-dijatimut-nezminno-do-24-sichnja

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:  -	The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no marking on the distance between customers of 1.5 m, and visitors do not have properly worn personal protective equipment.  -	The work of catering establishments from 23:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery and takeaway orders). Settlement operations are terminated after 22:00.  -	Activities of accommodation establishments (except for hotels, rehabilitation centers for people with disabilities, sanatoriums).  -	The work of gyms and fitness centers, if they have more than one person per 20 square meters.   -	Carrying out of discos, work of night clubs and public catering establishments with the organization of leisure.    /web/20210125185434/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

From 08 January until 24 January, "enhanced" adaptive quarantine measures are in place.  On 13 January, the "regular" adaptive quarantine measures were extended until 28 February.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210116231338/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-posileni-karantinni-obmezhennja-v-ukraini-dijatimut-nezminno-do-24-sichnja

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:  Carrying out mass events (performances, holidays, concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group / class and in the presence of visitors.  - Carrying out mass cultural (including concerts), sports, social, advertising and other events in which more than 20 people take part and the distance of 1.5 m between the participants is not observed (exception - official and professional sports events without spectators, notary exams and events necessary to ensure the work of the authorities).  - Carrying out in entertaining establishments and public catering establishments of celebratory actions, banquets, master classes, public events.  - Operation of cinemas and cultural institutions with more than 50% of seats in one hall.  - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries, there is more than one person per 10 square meters.  - Religious events: indoors - subject to the presence of more than one person per 5 square meters. m; in the open air - provided that the distance of 1.5 m between those present is not observed.    /web/20210125185434/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

School and university students are having academic holidays until January 11.   Links: https://archive.vn/pajju https://t.me/eduuz/3876
